description:
While everyone else on Mission street is running to El Farolito at 2 am, I come here. Never understood the hype around El Farolito anyways, but Taqueria San Jose can get it all day, everyday!

TACOS! Get 'em! And super size them bad boys up if you really know how to get down. Their super tacos are delicious and they load them up heavily with all of the goodies. That sour cream, though! They give you SO much of it! Never a dull moment with Taqueria San Jose. Some people swear by their al pastor, but I love their chicken tacos. Call me boring, but that ish is so good. 

I love their salsa, especially their pico de gallo. Even at 2 am, they always seem to have the salsa bar stacked. Yes it gets crowded on the weekends, but not nearly as bad as El Farolito. The guys behind the counter work really hard and they are always super friendly! They'll remember you when you come in often, all the way down to what you like to order and how you like to prepared. 

They keep it CLEAN! Hallelujah! Nothing is worse than coming from a party and then seeing all of the trash thrown around a restaurant from all of the lazy drunks nearby. They really try their best to keep it clean. I love that they're open until 3 am for all of the fat asses like myself that need a "beyond midnight snack" while out late in the city. It's on 24th and Mission, so super close to bart as well. 

It's a hole in the wall, but the food is good and much better quality than many of the other Taquerias on the block. Because of this, they are priced a bit higher but trust me: for the portions, taste, and quality, it's worth it. An excellent choice for delicious super tacos in the Mission!
author: Shayla B.

description:
Stopped here on a Saturday morning to get a breakfast burrito. It's super convenient that it's located right next to 24th St/Mission BART, and I figured I wanted to try a place I'd never been to before. Around 9am on a Saturday it wasn't busy at all, as expected and I ordered the chorizo super breakfast burrito. Probably try to bring cash unless you're coming with friends -- they do have a minimum for credit card so if you're getting multiple items it'll probably be okay but I had to pay cash for my burrito. Nice salsa bar.

The breakfast burrito was super satisfying, and the portions were v generous -- saved a little bit for later. Unfortunately, the only gripe I have with this place was that it took ages to get my food. There was another party eating in that was waiting for their food to be fair, but I waited for what felt like 20-25 minutes for my breakfast burrito, which is a little beyond my desired taqueria wait time, especially when it's not so busy. I would come back here, but left here a lot less excited than I was when I arrived.
author: Brian W.

description: Good solid taqueria in the Mission District. The prices are average but the sizes of each item are gigantic. We had milanese tortas and an al pastor super burrito. One torta could easily feed 2 people. One burrito could easily feed 2 people. The flavors here are done right. Good solid fare representing the Mission District very well. I'd return here and be happy for it.
author: Nicci L.

description:
Dropped by around midnight (Friday) and there was a group of people playing board games (hella hardcore). I think it's cool that a taqueria would open up their space for them - I literally had a flash to the past to the food court area of SFSU's Cesar Chavez Student Center. 

Food: Got the al pastor super burrito - BOMB! I have a low tolerance for spice and their salsa was spicyyyyyyy but it was soooo gooood. I was so full off of HALF.

I think I found my new favorite taqueria in SF (sorry Guads)!
author: Erika D.

description:
Solid, cheap, easy, tasty, Mexican food!

I got the super place and it came with two tacos beans and rice. Plenty of food tasty. I like that they have a lot of options for free salsa.

My husband got carnitas quesadilla and if huge and tasty.

The inside isn't super fancy, but pretty normal for a mission st authentic food experience. Great location as it's right next to the BART and easy to get to. Honestly if they had outside seating like the place next door they'd be in a really good place.

We ordered pickup online at Yelp and it was super easy to deal with. We will be back for sure!

Best,
Alyssa
author: Alyssa A.

description:
So my friend and I wanted to go to La Taqueria but they were closed because it was a Tuesday, so we ended up going here instead. They have a $10 minimum for credit cards so be prepared to eat or bring cash!

I ended up getting the two mini burritos for like $7 and I got lengua and buche. Both were decent, though they were very standard burritos. I think I would have preferred the tacos a lot more but they were advertising these mini burritos on a sign.

That being said, the burritos were pretty big for the price and I was quite surprised at how much I got. Beyond that though there wasn't anything too amazing or special about it.
author: Tyler T.

description: This place is bomb!  I don't really care for their super tacos just because if you want a super taco, you may as well just get a burrito.  But if you get their regular taco and throw some of their homemade pickled veggies and the green sauce on their... Nom Nom Nom!
author: Andrina H.

description: Just tried their al pastor taco and it's OMFG sooooo. Good I can't even love that you can grab any salude how much you want .
author: Sara F.

description:
Taqueria San Jose is steps away from the 24th and Mission BART station. 

I stopped by for lunch today and got a veggie burrito with guacamole. The burrito was huge. I split it with my boyfriend but still felt like I had a decent sized meal. The ingredients were pretty straightforward: the standard rice, pinto beans, guac, lettuce, and cilantro. The cilantro was the crowd pleaser. I was sad that the guacamole wasn't more flavorful- I'm a lady who loves lime, and the beans left a lot to be desired. That being said, the tortilla was thick and could've been made in house. It was definitely fresh. Theres a salsa bar available too (of course). Definitely take advantage of it and find your fave. The salsa will add a much needed kick to your dish.

All in all, I got a lot for my money and the food was decent. I'd be curious to try something else off the menu, but I don't know if or when I'll be back.
author: Kendall G.

description:
Open after midnight on Thanksgiving. That's not nothing. And in the state I was in, I v much appreciated it. 

I was... yeah you know what? I'm gonna continue to call it a state but I was ya know, having some perhaps alcohol related food cravings even after stuffing my face with some incredible homemade sushi that my friends crafted while I watched, caught them up on the recent happenings in my life, and was a real do-nothing, per usual. 

I guess I ordered too much food. It was like upwards of $40 somehow and the real redeeming piece of the order was the carrot juice, which I found to be primo. 

It took what seemed like 4 days for all our (my) food to come out and when it did, the quesadilla was for sure the least favorite. Hard to eat and the taste wasn't worth the trouble of cutting it. The nacho fries were p good if you go in under the influence of alcohol- if not... they are probably just on par. The camarones a la diabla was the level of spicy that I love, though I def paid for it for about half the day the next day. 

Would I go back? Probably not if there's anything else open, but if this is it and I'm super hungry and in need of sustenance I'd go for the carrot juice and fries.
author: Candice G.

description: Very underrated place. Very clean as well.  They have an actual roasting spit for their al pastor. So you know its legit.  I don't understand how other places don't do al pastor the right way.  Good selection of refreshing drinks. Very friendly. I recommend.
author: Joseph K.

description: Ate here for cinco de mayo. Too crowded and tables packed after lunch about 130pm. Tacos not good today. Menudo average. Get number on your receipt and the server will bring to you.
author: Clifford W.

description:
Yep. I'm hooked. I come here on average 2-3 times a month. Always a welcome and friendly staff that greet me. 

I'm a fan of the tacos and an occasional wet burrito, but lately the taco bowl has my heart.

Chicken is my favorite. Grilled it has a bit of a Smokey piquant flavor. If you are sensitive to the casual and a bit dated decor, maybe this isn't the place for you. Too bad, because you don't usually eat the decor. 

Do it. Come here. I'm promising you will become a fan too!
author: Stu S.

description: I am giving this restaurant a 5 stars because the menudo was so tasty and one of the best menudos I've ever had, service was also great and to my surprise the prices were reasonable, I also ordered 2steak tacos and the meat was tender and plentiful
author: Paul n.

description: Really good authentic Mexican comida!  They also have delicious sweet agua frescas.   Watermelon was delicious!  We had the super tacos con carne Asada.  Really Spicy too.  Yummy.  The employees were very sweet and accommodating.   Would definitely come back if in SF area.
author: Shelby F.

description:
Best Al Pastor tacos!

We have been going here for years. I remember the first time going, seeing the al pastor in the vertical spit-- I had to have it. I always anchor my orders in the pastor which is succulent and drips orange grease like chorizo. The tacos are huge.  Really an amazing amount of meat.  

I can't understand why the lines aren't longer.
author: Timothy L.

description: This is the thing . In San Francisco burritos runs and I've been to plenty a burrito spots , but I always keep coming back here if you want to get full and you have a budget come here I always get the burrito super style with two back to chips because I'm greedy AF LOL. They customer service always on point. Shout out to Victor,  Who took my order and not judge my weird request. Also on Fridays evenings they have game night you can bring your board game a couple of friends and a bucket of coronas and have a good time.
author: Maria R.

description:
Wow. I ate a lengua taco with guacamole here this weekend and I can't believe how much meat they load these things with. The portion of meat is beyond generous. There was so much lengua on the taco I can't even pick it up. Just a few bites and the weigh of the meat totally made the taco fall apart. This taco require utensils. The meat was nicely seasoned and tender. I wasn't very fond of the so called guacamole. It was more of a salsa and watery based guacamole. I was expecting chunks of avocado or even a thicker based guacamole. 

My burrito with guacamole was the same. Loaded with meat, cheese, beans, rice, sour cream and the watery guac. Although the guac did not live up to my expectation the meal itself was still very satisfying. The total spent for a taco, burrito and horchata came out to $14.00. To be honest, the meal could've fed two people but being the overeating American I chose to devour everything in front of me. It is fair to say I left the restaurant with a very happy tummy. Only feedback I can give them is work on your guac and I will be back.
author: Frank L.

description:
Ordered two sopes today, one chicken, one carne asada. Both were perfect in every way.

Sopes = little fried rounds of corn masa, topped with beans and meat = REAL Mexican food = delicious!

The beans were distinctive, the meats were flavorful, the masa was clean-tasting and crisp, not oily, and the salsa was fresh.  

Taqueria SJ is weird: twenty years ago their food was just acceptable. Then, maybe a decade ago, something went terribly wrong: food was stale and unappetizing. Then about two years ago, someone told me the food had improved. At first I didn't even want to take a chance, but when I did, I had to agree: everything I've ordered in the last few months has been delicious! 

What happened? Change in ownership? Blessed by Quetzalcoatl? I don't know, but I now consider SJ to be one of the best Mexican spots in the Mission!
author: Judy V.

description:
Dat cheese corn quesadilla doe. Oozing with cheese, omg..

I think it was a corn tortilla vs. flour, whatever it was, it was amazing.. 

Looking forward to going back for that..
author: Shruti D.

description: Hands down, best Carnitas Taco in the world. Stop looking elsewhere.  Walk drive or fly here today. Stop wasting time.
author: Jack L.

description:
This is my favorite taqueria in the Mission. The food is fairly standard but it is inexpensive and the portions a large. It has tons of seating so I can always bring in a big group with no notice (game night on Fridays is the exception). The staff are super-nice. Like most old-school small businesses in the Mission, they have $10 minimum for credit cards (or .75 fee) so if you are just stopping by for a taco, bring cash. 

When I go by myself or with one other person I like to sit on the "bar" area facing the front window and people-watch while I eat. They also have habanero peppers in their salsa bar, which I love.
author: Sarah C.

description: Taqueria San Jose is different from any other taqueria you'll find in the Mission. This restaurant has over 30 different platillos, featuring authentic Mexican cuisine such as tortas, mojarrita, carne adobada and several other dishes that are hard to find in other places. If you are tired of the same Mexican food (tacos, burritos and enchiladas) then Taqueria San Jose is the place for you. Five stars for this place not only because of the unique menu, but also because the restaurant stays open till late hours and has the best flan in town.
author: Jamie H.

description:
When a taqueria goes south, it can go way south...way, way south. I have no doubt Taqueria San Jose has seen better days and maybe I didn't give enough thought to my order here. After all, the little video snippet they posted under their Yelp business listing made the place sound so cozy, clean and family-friendly. Regardless, what Jamie W. and I had here was unequivocally miserable, and its proximity to the 24th Street BART station brought a whole transient element that made us feel like we were waiting for a bus to Bakersfield. And who wants to go to Bakersfield anyway?

I wasn't very adventurous with my selection of a quartet of soft tacos at $2.66 each, and in response, they didn't put much effort in putting them together. It looked like they cut the tortillas in quarters and served them up like hors d'oeuvres at a Mexican fiesta party at a singles mixer. I ordered two of them Lengua (beef tongue) and other two Carnitas (fried pork), the latter of which they smothered in a watery red sauce with what appeared to be a bushel of cilantro (photo: http://bit.ly/1NqpNLQ). The lengua were better simply because there was less sauce and more chopped onion for contrast (photo: http://bit.ly/1MGGhRb).

Jamie ordered smarter by getting the $12 Tacos Dorados Platillo. He also got four tacos but his actually looked like tacos in crispy corn tortilla shells, each filled with grilled chicken breast and the same watery red sauce I had. It came with lettuce, tomatoes, sour cream, rice, refried beans and some very tired looking mashed avocado passing for guacamole (photo:  http://bit.ly/1k9Bjjf). There wasn't anything remotely fresh about his platillo, and the gamey aura of the salsa station wasn't helping much either. I'm afraid I did find a way to San Jose, and frankly I'm OK if I go wrong and lose my way.

FOOD - 1.5 stars...disastrous tacos that didn't look like tacos and less-than-fresh sides
AMBIANCE - 2 stars...has my bus left yet?
SERVICE - 2.5 stars...they were fast, I'll give them that
TOTAL - 2 stars...making the savory unsavory with less-than-fresh meats & lazy flour tacos that don't satisfy
author: Ed U.

description: Great authentic Mexican Tacaqueri. We followed the aroma of food to this spot and we get right. Got the taco de cabeza, de pastor, and asada and chips and salsa. Everything was made to order and came out fast, and was good. Friendly staff, and super clean bathroom. Recommend as a stop in the area if you don't want a line.
author: Desiree R.

description: Best Carnitas in San Francisco, end of story.  I can't vouch for the rest of the menu because carnitas tacos are all I ever get.  Fresh carrot/orange juice too.
author: Paul M.

description:
The word gentrification is always used when talking about Mission Street and the surrounding areas. Sometimes it's a bad thing but sometimes it's a really good thing at the same time. And in the case of Taqueria San Jose, this place could use a heavy dose of gentrification and/or a total start over. 

You ever wonder where all the drug dealers come to roost and many of the folks walking around like zombies near the 24th and 16th Bart stations hang? It's at this taqueria.

But let's talk about the food:

Tacos Dorado: this was four hard shell steak tacos with rice and beans. The hard shells were stale! The meat was bland and rubbery. Worst Mexican food I've ever tasted.

Burrito Mojado: this was a terribly bland combination of ingredients. A total waste of at least 1000 calories that I wish I could take back. 

The service was fine, not really expecting much. The food on top of being bad was expensive at $25 for the two dishes. The terrible food is undesirable as the people who hang out here, it made me wish I had stuck to a sure thing across the street at El Farolito. So if you want meth or crack, come here. If you want food go anywhere on Mission Street and I'm pretty sure it will be better than this.
author: Michael L.

description: Incredible salsa roja and al pastor. Positively emulsified, yet incredibly, still so crispy. This place sets the damn standard!!
author: Brandon C.

description:
If you can find another taqueria that's open- go there, even McDonald's would be better than this place. 

Burritos are always soggy and awful looking (brown gauc, tough meat, dry rice). 
Nachos were soggy and just slathered together all messy.

Idk what happened bc they used to be okay, now I wouldn't even give it that high of a rating. 

Not to mention my stomach was killing me the entire next day...so there's also that...
author: Mandy F.

description: Finally, the place that got me into Mexican food! I had been a holdout for a long time, probably due to what I thought Mexican food was. I ended up going with friends, one of whom knew the cuisine very well. The result was excellent - burritos stuffed with beef, beans and fantastic sauce. I will definitely be back!
author: Aviah M.

description: I went to Taqueria  San Jose for breakfast today, i had a large plate of carne asada, beans, potatoes  and eggs. The food was good, but there was nothi special about it.  It felt like the people who work there aren't  having a good day.
author: Siarhei F.

description:
Excellent!  I had 4 tacos (lengua, cabeza, al pastor, and carne asada.  My wife had a veggie super burrito, and we split an order of carnitas super nachos.  An excellent combination of foods that we somehow managed to eat all of.  I was drawn to this place because they have a visible al pastor spit.  Many of the Bay Area mexican spots purport to serve al pastor pork but don't seem to use the whole spit technique.  

All 4 tacos were great.  Three days earlier I'd eaten a lengua burrito at el farolito, and I'm not sure I could say one was definitively better.  But this one was quite tasty, and it certainly wasn't worse than farolito.  The cabeza was my favorite, very tender and delicate.  The al pastor was good too, although it seemed like it may have had an added sauce, which may have been a bit overpowering.  

The carnitas nachos were also good.  I would get the same combo again. 

The place was not crowded at 6:30 on the Tuesday after Christmas.  A very change from throwing elbows at farolito.
author: Delaware F.

description:
I really did not find anything different or special about this restaurant. Food tasted exactly the way Chevy's or Chilli's food taste; generic and boring. Honestly, I am tired of the same food over and over, so I always intend to find places that have something different from other similar restaurants. 

Anyway, although food wasn't bad (I ate 100% of my Chicken Quesadilla with a side of Guacamole), I really felt that the food lacked creativity. It just looked like it was made in the most traditional way, and that's exactly the type of food I try to avoid. 

Not sure if I would return, not it other restaurants are open. I would not mind coming here if there was no other option, but it won't be my first choice.
author: Federica C.

description: Maybe I ordered the wrong thing. Tried this place based on reviews. Ordered an enchilada and got the reddest sauce I've ever seen had to be canned. Didn't taste that great at all.
author: Zak F.

description: Great place!  We always find our way there to eat when in the MIssion.  Fresh carrot juice is to die for, employees attentive and friendly (food took a little long to come out, but well worth the wait)!  Next time we're in the neighborhood you'll find us eating great food at Taqueria San Jose!
author: Cher P.

description: It's difficult to find an authentic Mexican taco shop in San Francisco but THIS. IS. IT. This place competes with some of the city's favorites, which are located on the same block (la taqueria and el farolito) and while the competition is tasty, Taqueria San Jose is simply the best because it serves up real authentic Mexican tacos the way they were invented and intended to be made. And at a very good price. Also, those free pickled potatoes after some salsa are an amazing idea. Yes, my review is for primarily for the tacos but why order anything else??
author: Gordon Z.

description:
No line when all other taquerias have 15+ people in line at 1:05pm on a Saturday.  7 people eating here.  3 workers.  Wait time for food from order to receiving: 3  mins.

Carnitas Super Burrito ($9.24 w/tax) was great.  No complaints.  Tons of flavor and meat.  No too fatty, see pics.  I will be coming back here.
author: Kailo R.

description: Considering all San Francisco Mexican food is garbage. Yes, I've been to LA taqueria, taqueria poncho villa, taqueria vallarta, taqueria guadalajara, etc. This is the best bang for your buck. Don't eat Mexican in SF. Period. Go to socal. If you must make your own. I am Mexican. I cook. Don't effing eat Mexican in Sf. If you like Mexican food in sf, you're either white or a coconut
author: Nestor A.

description:
Nachos are one of my favorite foods. It's actually not difficult to please me when it comes to nachos either. Chips, beans, cheese, meat, guac, sour cream, pico de gallo, jalepenos. Done. 

Taqueria San Jose came highly recommended for burritos, but I was jonesing for some super nachos last weekend when I was done hanging around the library, so I thought I'd give it the old college try. Well folks, if you get that same feeling, I'm guna recommend you save your $11.50 for literally anything else. The nachos were a huge let down. The ingredients weren't good: carne asada was unseasoned and gristly, the beans, guac, and sour cream were used very sparingly, the chips were stale, and they threw on a couple shreds of iceberg lettuce to finish it off. This was nachos gone all wrong. 

Thankfully my mama taught me to be creative with my food, so rather than toss them, I spruced these bad boys up at home, tossed them in the oven, added some cheese, cilantro, and fresh jalepenos, and viola! Edible nachos. But at the end of the day, when one spends almost $12 on a meal, they want it to taste good without having to go home and make it into something way better. This was a miss for me.
author: Crystal C.

description: Worse disgrace for Mexicans the I ordered  a regular burrito with carne asada got a vegetarian but I was hungry and ate it and it taste like s*** I could have made a better one myself at home and I ain't even Mexican man you need to go back to Mexico with that s*** that's garbage food
author: David G.

description: Horrible do not eat there bought 2 steak and 1 chicken burritos and all are meat was burnt
author: Tamara H.

description: Definitely one of the best taquerias i have ever been to. The restaurant itself is very clean unlike other taquerias i visited in the past. Salsa bar has many different options. I ordered just a single taco plate with chips & soda and was very fresh, filling & delicious. Every visit im welcomed & greeted by their friendly staff! This place rocks!
author: Tony S.

description: This place is legit. Never had carne asada here that I can't chew (you know what I mean).
author: Sharon J.

description: Pretty overpriced for some basic ass food. The $12 super nachos are a key example. Really nice staff, but unfortunately they're not edible.
author: Matt T.

description: So much delicious food, and it's relatively inexpensive. Perfect spot for late night tacos. My go to is a super veggie burrito, and I have yet to be let down. The environment is really friendly too, this is my go-to for late night tacos.
author: Jeremy D.

description: Best burritos in sf I been coming here for over 30 years I also enjoy the shrimp cocktail with a couple of tacos...and dinner plates are off the hook
author: Otto N.

description:
It's hard to screw up Mexican food but these folks have accomplished just that.

My veggie burrito was a huge disappointment, mostly because it *looked* so delicious when it was brought out. It was quite fat so I thought it would be loaded with goodness as any decent burrito should be. No such luck! Its bulk was mostly lettuce and the scant amount of beans they gave me were whole when I was told they'd be refried. The entire thing was so dry it fell apart when I tried to pick it up, so I resorted to cutting it with a blunt butter knife and fork- not an easy task since the tortilla was tough as leather! 

I was so disappointed by lack of beans that I went up to the counter to ask for more and had to pay $2.75 for them. They were delicious... but really? There was something floating in them too; I think it was waxed paper.

Chips were good but they cost extra and you only get one little cup for salsa.

What's more, the guy at the counter is sullen as hell and does not look at all pleased to have customers. Normally I would overlook this if the food was decent but not here. They're surrounded by endless other (better) Mexican places and should be polite to what customers they have left. 

I left feeling fleeced and frustrated and will not return.
author: Ellery D.

description: Pretty good tacos. Perfect for a quick lunch. Wish there were more toppings and wish all the proteins weren't cooked next to each other. As a person who doesn't eat pork, I don't like the idea that it could have been mixed. Two tacos for $5, is a great deal and filled me up.
author: Samantha E.

description: Food was fire! Tasted and looked so fresh. They made my shrimp and steak super burrito with some TLC!
author: Juan S.

description: Wow, had the Al pastor taco with guacamole, was awesome! Only downside was salsa wasn't Mexican hot.
author: Christopher F.

description: I really like the one in San Rafael. The food was  good and service ok but rest was lacking
author: Mark M.

description: I like their burritos and like I said in the prior review nice guys behind the counter.  This taqueria is next to the BART station and some scruffy do wander in to eat.  The guys behind the counter are nice with them and never try to hurry anyone out.  Food is fine and its just a place where I feel really comfortable
author: Mark P.

description: The best legit deal in town for a huge baby burrito that is the size of my forearm. It can have meat or be veg! Also if you buy 2, then it's $7 (I'm veg). Today I can in randomly & got 1 beef for my aunty & a veg for myself as well as 3 salsas & freshly made chips for $8! I used to go to La Corneta, La Altena, & other ones  in Excelsior. But for $4, huge baby baby burritos are a must! I am now a devout client to this place cuz it's clean, fast, tasty, convenient & of course affordable! You must get your baby burritos now!
author: R C.

description: Some of the worst Mexican food I've had in a long while. Got the enchilada plate. Didn't eat the chicken enchilada as it tasted super gross. Old dry and gamey. Yuck. Everything else was bland as hell. Not even mediocre. Much much lower than than. Won't be coming back with so many other great spots in the immediate area.
author: Jason P.

description:
Saturday morning I walked in to order a couple of burritos. I had never gone here in the morning before. The few times I've gone here, has been after midnight. Never had a problem with my order. 
Food always tasted good. Saturday morning was a different story. I ordered a super carne asada burrito. With everything on it except lettuce and hot sauce. The nice lady assured me that it does not come with lettuce. Cool I thought. I HATE LETTUCE IN MY BURRITO!!! 
Then I ordered my friend's burrito. She's vegan. So I know how to order her burrito. I saw a sign for their grilled veggie burrito. It sounded perfect for her. The nice lady at the counter walked me through the burrito and what it all came with. "This burrito comes with lettuce. Do you want lettuce? I asked for all the veggies it came with except zucchini and lettuce. Then she asked me if I wanted cheese and sour cream. I CLEARLY TOLD HER NO SOUR CREAM. NO CHEESE. "No sour cream n cheese?" she asked again. AGAIN I said NO CHEESE NO SOUR CREAM, NO LETTUCE. By the way, I ordered in Spanish. So I know there was no language barrier. The nice lady understood my order. I saw her clearly mark down the instructions for the burrito maker to follow. I ate my burrito there while I was waiting for my friend to show up. We had a long ride ahead of us. She decided to take her burrito (the veggie one) with her and eat it when we got to where we were going. An hour later. We get to our destination. She is hungry. She couldn't wait for that "Grilled Veggie Burrito" that I had described to her. She starts to unwrap her big burrito. She was talking about and waiting for this moment the whole morning. 
She takes a big bite. CHEESE AND SOUR CREAM. CHEESE AND SOUR CREAM. CHEESE AND SOUR CREAM!!!! She almost cried. I was furious. It also had LETTUCE in it. I was an hour away so I couldn't just go back with that burrito to show it to them. We couldn't bring food and I wasn't about to carry a burrito with me all day. Believe me I was so upset I wanted to. I failed my friend and it ruined our morning. I think there needs to be more accurate communication between whoever writes down the orders and whoever reads them and makes them. Get it right!
author: Stormtrooperfiftytwo E.

description: All I can say it try the al pastor super taco. It made me fall in love with al pastor. I also love the fact that the they offer radishes along with peppers at the salsa bar. The chips aren't the greatest, but who goes to a taqueria for the chips?
author: Eric K.

description: It was late and we wanted some Mexican food since most places were closed after 9pm, we ran into this location and decided to give it a try. I only good thing about this place is the fresh house made aqua frescas. We ordered carne asada plate the food was cold, no flavor, no taste, it was bad. the ceviche was horrible. Not coming to this place anymore. To top it off they charge for chips,  chips that taste horrible.
author: Rosa R.

description: In shock my parents went here tonight to buy 4 burritos when they checked out they man automatically charged a 18% gratuity when my dad asked why the cashier said "they have the right to do that bc it's there choice to add" so watch your receipt closely! When we called back they said we can come back and get our money! They are illegally adding tips! Burritos were very dry too!
author: Pete Y.

description: You have many choices in the Mission for greasy food. This is, an okay place. I went here about a month ago with a group friends, and ordered myself a nice, meaty quesadilla. It was on the greasy side, but tasted pretty damn good. You have to pay extra for chips, and that's not too cool. There was plenty of places to sit, at least when I was there, and it was a Saturday. If you want something for the long haul of night drinking, this is a good place to start.
author: Joel G.

description: Randomly stepped in here for lunch. Got two super  tacos (al pastor and carnitas). They were freaking huge and delicious. Can't think of a better way to review them. I will definitely go here again.
author: Andy G.

description:
Saturday afternoon. Carne asada super burrito.

Server seemed bored and uninterested. Food was okay. Not great, not good, but okay. Tortilla was flaky and fell apart. Carne asada was mediocre and tasted plain. Guac was not great either.

Considering the ridiculous amount of excellent options for taquerias in the area just across the street and down the block, "okay food" doesn't really cut it. I would not return here.
author: Victor S.

description:
My friend and I were frantically hunting for Mexican food on New Years Eve around our usual places at 24th/Mission. You know what cravings I'm talking about. Everything near the BART station was pretty much closed except for Taqueria San Jose. SCORE!!

We both shared the Super Nachos ($11) which adds guacamole, sour cream, and cheese onto the regular nachos. Everything tasted mushed together, but we were craving Mexican food so it was still very satisfying. In fact, for some reason it made me crave Taco Bell. Anyways, there is plenty of seating here, so you don't have to worry about taking your food to-go on most occasions. Props that they accept credit cards with no minimum and were open on NYE when nowhere else was.
author: Stefanie C.

description: This place was amazing! Loved the tacos and enchiladas. I could not stop eating the salsa and pico. The beans and rice were not too salty. So good.
author: Kimberly S.

description:
Love this place. So convenient 2 block away from us. Good food and drinks...... 10+.  Highly recommend. 
They open late and always pack. Recommend rsvp 1st
author: gigi t.

description: really good service. had a good first few bites and spent the rest of my meal trying not to gag. also an employee was confused when asking for forks ?
author: Emma S.

description:
If you are looking for a shitty, expensive, and just not good at all taco go here. Also, if you want stale chips that you have to pay for go here too.

I rather go across the street to la taqueria, or el farolito.
author: Davis E.

description:
THE BEST BURRITO IVE EVER HAD!!!
it was one of those situations where you don't want the meal to end so when the burrito was almost finished I started taking smaller bites and prolonging the enjoyment
author: Jeff D.

description:
Best street taco joint in town. The carne asada is juicy and chock full of flavor.
Thr ultimate meal here is frijoles and rice and ensalada and al pastor tacos
Jalapeno pepper radishes spicy salsa verde grilled mexican green onions lime quarters and an icy tamarindo melon or
orchata and or pollo asada or carnitas on a plato with all of the above. No other tacqueria in the mission comes close to their al pastor. The menudo is suitably spicy and the birria is through the roof.
Foodie heaven. But kept real. Find out yourself. This is it.
author: Bob R.

description: Nothing to complain about, just didn't quite match the El Farolito's and Papalote's of the world for me.
author: Steffan P.

description:
Cannot believe all the high scores this place.

Single bite into a burrito al pastor, it oozes red thick oily substance. Like a bad pimple on a burrito that never ends.  The al pastor is tastless and full of fatty oil.  Chucked it after 2 bites.  No flavor what so ever, first time pork fat does't rule.  I rarely waste food.  Rather in the garbage than in my belly.

The al pastor they have in the picture is for show, I saw the cook got mine from a special stash in the cabinet.  Guess he gave me special stuff that they save for special guests.

Ask yourself why does the al pastor the have in the picture and in store so picture perfect.  Do they ever cut from it?  Is it wax or real?

Sorry, hate to write these terrible thoughts, my fav is still Gordos and many others.

All the folks in this place on a evening (2 others in an empty place) was not even latino... another tall tale sign.

Yes I have been to Mexico several times, never seen this low grade quality products.
author: David H.

description:
The "first" taqueria in SF? PUH-LEASEEEE...that's like me saying, "I'm skinny" and we all know that's a damn LIE. 

After having yet another disappointing drunken meal; yes, you would think I would have learned my lesson by now but this time I SWEAR it wasn't my fault. We somehow ended up at Taqueria San Jose Sunday morning when I told my friend to drive to Mexico Tipico. I guess someone was drunkER than the rest of us. :T 

Upon walking into Taqueria San Jose and seeing all hipster and no natives, I already knew this was going to be bad. However, looking at the menu seemed a bit more promising because they had lengua and cabeza which only more authentic taquerias tend to have. 

SUPER LENGUA BURRITO w/ No Rice, No Beans, & No Cheese (crazy looks from the cashier not pictured)
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/r0N9vb7G4Us8HEG20v4NkA?select=6jk8Ka25SHFWq7F3hNbsvg
My burrito was one disappointing soggy log. The juices from the pico de gallo made the tortilla limp and wet. The copious amounts of crema was overwhelming and made each mouthful difficult to eat. The lengua? What very little lengua there was, were diced in microscopic cubes; the onions in the salsa were larger than the lengua pieces. The lengua was not braised long enough as it had a tough and hard texture. It was like eating a burrito after it has been weathered in a rain storm; several bites in, I threw in the towel.

One of my friends drunkenly threw a slice of carne asada in my basket which was equally as bad. The tough as shoe leather carne asada was cold, dry, and flavorless. http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/r0N9vb7G4Us8HEG20v4NkA?select=dTy_2rRSgJwpAaxu08YAAg

Just because you're catering to the drunk crowd at 2 AM doesn't mean you can serve subpar food and for some of them to not take notice. Nothing can phase this drunktard's taste buds. 

One star for being clean and well-lit. 
One star for the delicious salsa verde. 

***HITS THE REMIND BUTTON***

Back to the start of the review, as I was walking to the bathroom, I remember seeing a sign saying that Taqueria San Jose was the first taqueria to open in SF in 1980 (makes no sense even sober). To confirm that I wasn't being delusional, I checked their website which Taqueria San Jose does state themselves as the first taqueria in SF to open in 1980 under "our history". Ummm, if you're going to lie, please do a better job. La Cumbre was the first taqueria to open in SF in 1967. I knew ALL those hours vegging on the couch watching Man vs. Food would come in handy one day. Thank you, Adam Richman!

OTHER NOTES:
*Closes at 3 AM on weekends
*Plenty of seating
*Free chips
*Salsa bar only has pico de gallo, salsa rojo, and salsa verde
*Near 24th/Mission Bart stop
*CC's accepted
author: Cherylynn N.

description: Solid taqueria in the mission. The dining area is large and the line doesn't get too long. i got a lengua super burrito and it was very flavorful. They have good aqua frescas too -- I got the strawberry and it was yummy.
author: Sherry L.

description: Went here with a friend one day looking for burritos and ended up with a carnitas burrito and chicken taco. The food was good but average at best. It was no more expensive than your general Mexican place, with about $8 for the burrito. The taco was definitely a bit overpriced and with the quality of it, I felt like I could have gone without it. Mainly because the burrito itself comes huge and packed. Overall, the place is an average stop if you're looking for a decent spot to eat as you're walking the city.
author: Denzel D.

description:
A lot of people review this place as a comparison to El Farolito, and while I can see the resemblance (open late, on opposite corners of the same intersection, and same category of food) I don't think it's necessarily a fair comparison as they offer rather complementary features. 

1. Taqueria San Jose has more space, bar none. So much so, they host a Friday night board game night (or maybe magic the gathering? Scrabble? I can't always tell, but I think it rotates or they host a mix). 

2. UPDATE: they no longer take credit cards :( Taqueria San Jose takes credit cards, and if it bothers them that I spend ~$6 each time, they never let on.

3. Taqueria San Jose almost never has a line. I can usually order, pay, and be out the door with my grub in 5 minutes or less.

4. Taqueria San Jose night shift rocks! I think the food is better after 8pm because it's busier, which means the food is fresher. I've only heard complaints from people not sober enough to judge, or people who came during the day... But this could totally be coincidence/superstition.

5. Taqueria San Jose's super taco is my jam (I've never had anything else). I might get the pollo adobo or al pastor if I'm especially hungry/hankering for some grease in my gullet (if you're hungry but don't want the grease, the pollo adobo is your best bet), but the vegetarian super taco is usually a satisfactory quantity of food. It's a fork and knife endeavor when you eat it out of the to-go container, or on a plate you can try to separate the tortillas to make two large/messy tacos. My only (small) gripe here is, even though it's *exactly* the amount of food I want (which helps with portion control), it's about 2/3 the price of a burrito, but only 1/3 the amount of food. Evaluating price per calorie, this is not strictly budget-friendly, but it's awesome if you're looking to fill your belly to a reasonable bloat on less than $6 without leftovers.

Mostly I guess I'm just impatient. I think the food is (all things considered-- remember, I've only eaten the super taco, and that's not something El Farolito offers) just as good as their neighbor, but I don't like to wait in line/make sure I have cash/be forced to take it to-go because there aren't enough seats inside. As such, Taqueria San Jose is my hidden-in-plain-sight gem.
author: Krista L.

description: Given its location, it can be overshadowed by neighboring La Taqueria and El Faritlo - but definitely give Taqueria San Jose a shot. The breakfast burritos are bar none, and you can get any burrito as a baby burrito size, for when a full sized burrito belly seems like a bit too much.
author: Emily F.

description: Went walking around SF with friends and got suuuuper hungry. Found this place only .3 miles from us and OMGGG it's amazing! I ordered the super burrito of carne asada and it was huge! With rice, beans, cream, meat and guacamole for only $8! A great meal for cheap? That's what I'm talkin about!
author: Marisol M.

description: They should use salt and pepper at least when cooking meat. Had to eat only cuz I was very hungry
author: Fabian E.

description:
Went here one time when waiting in line for a burrito at La Taqueria or El Farolito seemed too overwhelming.  Big mistake.  I ordered an al pastor super burrito and it was genuinely horrible.  The al pastor seemed to have tons of gristle, and I had to throw my burrito out less than a third of the way through.

It's hard to think that anyone could combine tortillas, rice, guacamole, salsa, sour cream, cheese, and meat and end up with something bad, but the folks at Taqueria San Jose seemed to accomplish the feat.

Go literally anywhere else.
author: Victoria P.

description: One random evening, my boyfriend and I stumbled into Taqueria San Jose to try out some micheladas....the best idea we ever had! Til this day! So much flavor and the perfect amount of spicyness! The tacos &burritos aren't bad either! This is a real hole in the wall for me! My bf & I call it our "big meech" spot, cuz with these micheledas, you can never go wrong!
author: Ruby G.

description: Must go place for Tacos de Camarones:) I really like them. Their salsa is also awesome!!! And it's in a nice location which is next to the Bart station.
author: Maitai N.

description:
You ever had dinner at a friend's house and you ate the meal as to not offend the host? That was me with the bbq pork burrito. It was "meh" at best.
And on top of the limited food experience I had there, I can say the ambiance is not very inviting. The salsa bar was tucked away far from the register and all closed up with no indicators around it that we should approach this makeline cold case, much less open it up and help ourselves to whatever could be inside it.
The staff were great though! Just an unfortunate taqueria.
author: J C.

description:
You either love this place or you hate it. You can group me with the former. I suppose it's because Taqueria San Jose was the first place I ever tried a Mission-style burrito, many years ago. Back then they had a second location directly across the street from this one! Nowadays the place has a fresh coat of paint, is much cleaner and the restrooms are pretty nice.

TSJ has the the biggest burritos I have come across anywhere in the Mission, which is saying a lot. They are a bit juicier than others as well. That might turn some people off but I like the extra moisture. You're guaranteed never to get a dry burrito. My usual order is an al pastor super burrito, no beans. Most places will just serve you a smaller burrito if you order one without beans, but TSJ ups the amount of meat and rice to make up for it. Solid. The al pastor is always juicy and flavorful but can sometimes lack those crispy edges that make it something special.

I miss living around the corner from this place. How much do I miss it, you ask? I once drove 10 burritos home to LA, froze them and rationed them out over the next few months. True story.

p.s. I just read a two star review by a woman who complained about the lettuce making her burrito watery. What did she expect?! TSJ doesn't put lettuce on their burritos. The fact that she special ordered one with lettuce should automatically cancel out her review.
author: Matthew D.

description: Been here a few times. I always get the carnitas b/c they make them crispy here. Sometimes it's awesome w/ the perfect combination of crispy and tender. Sometimes it's way too dry. Burrito was a bit bland and not very well mixed, but their salsas (chile verde!!), horchata and customer service are always bomb!
author: Kim D.

description: I have made this a stop before many business trips, just before flying for many 10+ hour flights.
author: Jeff Y.

description:
Food looked really good!  I posted a pic!   But it was bland.... :(  So peculiar!!  

We had lengua & al pastor tacos and a Chicken burrito.  All were not very flavorful.   lol, even the pico was bland (but spicy!).  How is that possible??  

Good service, the guy was really nice.
author: CatwomanRoar M.

description: This is my favorite taqueria in the Mission. The food is always so great and the staff are super friendly!
author: Erica S.

description:
To be honest they were quite the disappointment for me, unfortunately. Burrito was a bit of a watery mess thanks to the drenched lettuce. Towards the end, burrito juice was running down my arm and the tortilla was soggy. Not only that overall flavor was somewhat bland. Chips (which tasted of the bagged variety) are 85 cents.

Service was fine. The person who took my order was fine. I noticed there was only one person working the kitchen. But then again this was in the evening, an hour or so before closing. 

Too bad. I wish I liked them. It would be easy to pick up a quick dinner here in the evening as I exit off 24 Street BART.
author: Esther A.

description: I'm not a breakfast person. If I MUST be up early and need some food in my belly, its gonna be lunch/dinner food. Right before a tattoo I'm gonna need some serious grub (read: BURRITO). Taqueria San Jose to the rescue! They serve their entire menu starting at 8 am. Not only was my burrito al pastor very large for 7.95, it was made quickly. Their al pastor is the truth! That plus the fresh pico de gallo and the fluffy rice made this one of the best burritos I've had in the mission. I'll be back for more serious breakfast.
author: Sunshine R.

description:
New Year's Eve and the craving for Mexican food was strong. My friend and I walked around for so long trying to find a place that was open. We were both so excited when we finally saw the open doors at this place. 

We shared an order of Super Nachos and it was decent, but ain't got nothing on El Farolitos. They were generous with the amount of meat though and their pico was better. The nachos themselves were mushed up but it was a great way to satisfy my cravings. Props to being open on NYE!
author: Winnie T.

description:
This is the first (and so far only) place I've ever thrown away food from in San Francisco.

Ordered an al pastor burrito around 8:30pm one night.  It was far too greasy, with red al pastor grease literally streaming (not even dripping) out of the bottom of the burrito.  Maybe it was just my bad luck, but the first 3 bites were also mostly gristle.

Thew the whole thing away and went elsewhere.
author: Paul C.

description: Worst burrito i have ever had. And i've had a some bad burritos. Only one of the salsas was even edible. I've heard the street tacos are good, but nothing could make up for that burrito.
author: John F.

description:
We come by Taqueria San Jose on the occasional Friday night to join the SF nerds for board game night (random people bring board games and you just join in, every Fri at 7pm)

Luckily, in addition to this place having a lot of space for people to spread out and play board games, their food is quite good too. Our favorite is their carnitas meat, which whether loaded into a burrito, torta, or taco is incredible flavorful, generously served, and reasonably priced.
author: Amy D.

description: It's okay, burrito was good. Not spectacular but still good. Even though there was a piece of paper in my burrito at the end. Also, the 2 burritos ordered were ready really fast, so that's a plus
author: Erich P.

description: Came here at 2am for Halloween and it was crazy packed. Other than that, it was soooo good. I got the al pastor burrito and it was delicious. Everything comes with free chips and salsa. Overall great experience and I would definitely come back.
author: Samanyha O.

description: This place is the perfect example of a business based on fleecing the guest. Your a Mexican restaurant but you charge for chips and salsa, limes and even ice in your complimentary water. No salsa bar so you have to ask for it which is an extra charge. A good example is that Nachos are $7.50 but Super Nachos are $12. What kind of meat cost an extra $4.50 to add?? Just another business trying to prosper on stupid white people that insist on hanging out on the mission. FML...
author: Santana T.

description:
For a long time my 24th and Mission burritovision was tunneled In on El Farolito,  however, after a long time missioner raved about Taqueria San Jose, I widened my view just a bit.

I got an Al Pastor super burrito and found it to be crazy flavorful.  It had just the right mixture of spicy and tangy to keep my taste buds happy for the whole burrito.  San Jose seems to go a bit lighter on the rice than El Farolito, instead opting for more meat, salsa, and grac to stuff their burrito.  This didn't write work for me, but I imagine for some people it will be awesome.

Perhaps due to the lack of rice, the burrito also super greasy. I can imagine this might be a good thing if you're stopping by after a night out, but it may give you feelings of regret during the daytime.  It didn't ruin my experience, but it may for you.

The one area where San Jose is lacking is burrito construction.  The bottom of mine fell apart pretty quickly, so I was left to cleanup the leftovers with a fork.

Nonetheless, clean up all the leftovers I did, as the deliciousness of the Al pastor made up for all the downsides.  San Jose hasn't unseated El Farolito in my mind, but it's definitely a respectable entrant in the mission burrito rotation.
author: Jonathan M.

description: My favorite spot in the whole 24th and Mission area. Tacos de lengua are delicious. Salsa is pretty fresh. And the aguas frescas are pretty good. My fave are the quesadillas. Restrooms are fairly clean also. Always gotta stop by if I'm in the neighborhood.
author: Georgina B.

description: I usually get their super nacho, and I think it's the best I've had in the mission. Always give you a lot and never stingy about meat or avocado !
author: Keith A.

description: I've been going to Taqueria San Jose for many years. If you want a great burrito, I recommend El Pollo al pastor burrito. It has the Great Taste of al pastor without the pork. This is one of the very few  places that have chicken al pastor.
author: Ronald M.

description:
Cash only, what is this an illegal run business in Mexico, $1 for a batch of stale chips, rude cashiers. 
It's the only thing open this late and I was starving, so nex time I will plan ahead and avoid this place at all costs
author: Roger Z.

description:
We had a ceviche tostada and chorizo, carne asada, and carnitas taco.  There was a lot of meat in the tacos.  Salsa wasn't spicy, but tasty. The tacos ate made with the small tortillas.  I always like the pickled carrots and radishes at the self serve area, you can get as many as you like :)

The pastor meat looked really good, but I was full.
author: Lisa R.

description:
SOLID four stars.

now, as you may know, i preach about how amazing tacos are in san diego because it's where i lived the past four years.  i've been on the hunt for a replacement late-night mexican restaurant for quite a while.

this is my TENTATIVE replacement.

i've eaten here twice and gotten takeout twice.

i LOVE that they have different kinds of salsa because.... that's my thing.  i don't LOVE any of them, but i do love variety :)  

i REALLY like their super burrito because it's HUGE and mixed the perfect amount.  

i also really enjoyed their tacos because of some special spicy pico de gallo they put on it.  i wish they put that salsa in their burritos!!

the variety of food they have here is nice!  it's also decently priced and there's plenty of room to sit :)  the guys working there are also super nice and patient (because i take forever deciding). i hear this place is open really late too!!  wish i lived closer or else i would come here more often.  SF needs some more late night drunken munchie places.
author: Jennifer L.

description:
Awesome burritos- big and flavorful. My parents used to come here when it was starting 25 years ago. Still good!  I wish they were cheaper so I could come here more often but they are not bad, about $7-8. Make sure to add the green salsa and pico de gallo too. 
The enchiladas were okay but the burritos are the star of this place.
author: Hannah F.

description: The only positive thing I can say about this place is that they accept debit. The food was very tasteless and dissatisfying. I ordered a Carne Asada super burrito and was very disappointed by the lack of flavor, no amount of salsa could compensate for the flavor.
author: Reina C.

description:
I first moved to the US 2 years ago and my wife took me here for my first super burrito and I have never looked back! 

I've now eaten my fair share of burritos but there's something about the way they cook the meat, especially the carnitas, that really makes them. 

Their salsa bar is always full and ready to be taken advantage of. Would recommend this place to anyone!
author: Max R.

description:
ASK FOR CHIPS!! Salsa is on the side counter.

This place gave me the most delicious nachos with pork. Yummmmmyyyy. A couple of friends got drinks from next door, I brought the nachos over, and it was more than enough for everyone to snack on. $8 wasn't too shabby of a deal!

I didn't try anything else at the location, but the service seemed fast. This is a in and out type of restaurant, I didn't stay for long, so I don't really have anything to say about the ambiance. 

If I find this place again with friends, I will be back.
author: Christina L.

description:
this Taqueria San Jose must be the black sheep of all them name-alikes. it's the priciest and least tasty.

cleanliness they exceed at. (much cleaner than oaktown)
roomier than san rafael.

eats: lengua burritos (6.99)
-tender lengua, what there was
-so so salsa, rice, bean mix
-quick, cordial service
-quality food, no (chemical) aftertaste
2.5 stars

frijoles refritos:
-value isn't present. 2 stars.
-heartell al pastor is excellent here...
author: Victor G.

description:
This place ranks high on my list of reasons to miss San Francisco.

Hands down, best burrito I've ever eaten.
author: Connor I.

description:
Taqueria SJ is my favorite taqueria in SF.  They give you FREE chips and 2 small containers to fill with their salsa at the salsa bar.

Tacos are only $2.21 so cheaper than La Taqueria.  

We got:
al pastor taco- bbq pork.  Very tasty.
lengua taco - lots of meat, tasty.
cabeza - beef head - nice
ceviche tostada $2.5 - lots of chopped up marinated red snapper w/ onions & sliced ripe avocado - nice
medium strawberry drink $2.10 - nice

All for about $12.  I saw a sign for credit cards, but we paid cash.

Separate bathrooms in the back.  Next to 24th Bart Station.
author: Ann L.

description: This place meets all expectations. The food was really good. We went on a Saturday and the Caldo de Res (Beef soup) was really good full of flavor and they accommodated my request of ordering just half a bowl. We also ordered the carnitas burrito which the meat was really good but the rest of the fixings where lacking taste. Regardless it was really big, something to just share between two people for sure. Highly recommend this place, much easier to order and less hassle than Taqueria. Also the dinning area accommodates a bigger group with plenty of room to sit and enjoy your meal.
author: Frank C.

description: Gave this place a shot when the other places around didn't take credit card- and I'm not gonna lie, this is probably one of the worst burritos I've ever had, and coming out at around $10, was by no means cheap (especially since I now have to buy a second dinner after eating almost none of it). Got a chicken "super burrito" mainly for the guacamole, of which none could be found. Flavors managed to be both bland and unappetizing, nothing tasted fresh, and the chicken tasted "gristly", with a really odd consistency. As a benchmark, Chipotle is about 1000x better. Next time I'll remember my cash and actually check out Taqueria El Farolito like I'd first planned!
author: Alice T.

description:
My wife and I were jonesing for a late evening treat before getting on the BART to head back to East Bay. We'd just spent a number of hours at a bar and had then headed to Mission district to check out the Dia de los Muertos action, so we were still a little tipsy.

We decided to order quick food - Tacos and a Quesadilla. My wife's Tacos were an A-, my Quesdilla was a solid A. I don't remember the kind I ordered, but it had Guac and sour cream inside, and I'd never had it that way before. Mighty tasty, in my opinion. The salsa was fine (tried both green and red) - nothing spectacular, but satisfying. My wife's Horchata was a little gritty - she didn't mind so much, but that's not how it should normally be served. 

The place was packed at 11 PM, mostly with people from the evening's festivities, and the employees were doing a bang up job considering the circumstances. 

BTW, I find all the Groupon people reviewing this place to be rather whiny. Stop being cheapskates and actually review a place on the food for a change.
author: Andrew L.

description: I have now had their chicken burrito a few times now. The sauce that the chicken is stewed in is so delicious. Flavorful but not overly spicy. It is also so large that it serves as dinner and also lunch the next day.... Just watch for dripping of the sauce through the to go bag. Even better, bring your own container
author: Miri R.

description:
This is my Go-To Taco spot when I'm at 24th and Mission. Sure , there are a lot of places to go in the Mission, but if I'm headed home from Bart - you better believe that I'll be stopping off for a Super Taco. 

The super tacos are so big, I like to use chips and treat it like nachos until it gets down to something I can handle. I usually just order one, not because I'm a cheap date, but because they are huge. 

Yes you have to pay for chips now, but in these economic times ~ $1.50 for a huge order of chips is not going to break the bank. Get over it. I overheard this guy complaining about it, saying he was going back to Noe Valley where the chips are free. I laughed my a** off, Taco + Chips + Salsa + Free Comedy for under $6.00.
author: Rebekah T.

description:
I had a super burrito with al pastor.  The only thing super about it was it's size, and the guac was pretty fresh and tasty.

The burrito itself was not unlike an old man sans viagra: limp and prone to premature ejaculation, as it fell apart only 4 bites into my dinner.

Needless to say, I was sad and disappointed that this was my last meal before i left.
author: Tony N.

description:
Chicago is famous for its pizza, Philadelphia for its cheesesteaks and Kansas City for its barbecue. San Francisco's claim to Roadfood fame is the burrito, the best examples of which can be found in the city's Mission district. Located half a block from the 24th Street BART station, Taqueria San Jose has been lauded year after year by various local publications for having the best burritos in the Mission and therefore the best in the city. It won't take you long to figure out why.

Formica tables and plastic chairs crowd the unassuming storefront, decorated with the paintings of well-endowed senoritas and matadors, mariachi music or a soccer match on TV providing the soundtrack. But one comes not for the ambiance, but for the food. Place your order at the counter, pick up your basket of freshly fried tortilla chips, load your little plastic cups at the salsa bar (go for the outrageously fresh-tasting pico de gallo and/or guacamole), and munch away until your number is called to pick up your food.

The burritos are, in a word, humongous. Two-fisted eating at its finest, a massive fresh flour tortilla stuffed with your choice of meat, rice, refried beans, cheese, sour cream, salsa and guacamole. If you're not burrito-minded, you won't go wrong with the fajitas, meat and peppers and onions heaped high, or the tacos. Think there's no such thing as non-greasy chorizo sausage? Then you haven't eaten a Taqueria San Jose chorizo taco, redolent of spices that are eased by sour cream and another freshly made tortilla and not a speck of grease in sight or on palate.

Taqueria San Jose has two other locations closer to the touristy sections of San Francisco and I'm told that the quality is the same, but when in doubt, go to the original. I can also say that the leftovers from a carnitas (pork) burrito make a pretty darn good breakfast. 

PS--this is a re-post of my Roadfood.com review, which, I am proud to say, is now framed and hanging in the shop.  I wonder if I'd get a free burrito if I showed my ID ... ?
author: Patricia B.

description: From out of town and had heard of the mission district burritos. Tried the other places there was no place to sit. Found this place and found food to be outstanding.
author: Ed L.

description:
I haven't been to this taqueria since Clinton was our president. It has changed and gotten a lot cleaner. The price has increased since the last time I was at SJ Taqueria. $8.00 for super-burrito and soda,it's still cheaper and tastier than (what's that place on 16th and Mission called?) They give a score of 100 for cleanliness. It has changed. The lavatory is cleaner with no graffittis. 

In 1999, i used the bathroom, I see all the Tags and graffittis on the wall. The most stupid one I saw written was,"DON'T WRITE ON WALL"
That made me wanna pee on the wall to wash out the written request. Now this place is better and cleaner,even my piss on the wall is gone.

Oh yeah, the place on 16th and Mission is "Pancho Villia", that place is expensive and mediocre.
author: Matt G.

description:
The people who work there are not nice. 

The food does not taste good. 

It takes FOREVER to get your order. 

I'm not sure how this place has as many stars as it does. There are so many other amazing taqueria's in the mission.
author: Alex W.

description: Recently discovered this place and I was not disappointed. They have menudo and birria on the weekends super yum. A lot of choices and al pastor on trompo! Definitely as much as I can
author: Montserrat S.

description: Like everything here! Staff are friendly! Always busy there! Food is fresh! Downfall: Bathroom is gross
author: Susie C.

description:
I'm not sure why I never found this place before! 

After the line at El Farolito was out the door at midnight, we ended up at Taqueria San Jose for some of the fattest burritos I've had in a long time. They had friendly service, mouthwatering carnitas, and they were serving sangria long after most places had stopped serving at all. 

A friend got the al pastor burrito as well, and I almost ate hers too. I usually go to La Taqueria when I'm in this stretch, but I think I just found a competitor.
author: Kevin B.

description:
I usually go to Taquerias El Farolito
I was pulling up and there was a spot right in front of San Jose. I parked and decided to give it a try.
It was awful. I got the enchiladas
They were cold and stale tasting. 
Taquerias El Farolito there is no comparison!
author: Ken B.

description:
Disappointing.

After several attempts (the woman at the counter had a very strong accent) I managed to order a burrito, though she got the drink order wrong. They won't put salsa on a burrito, they want you to open the wrapped burrito and add it from their self-serve bar. This of course means the burrito will fall apart. They also don't put napkins out, nor did they give me any with my burrito. There are good taquerias in the mission, this isn't one of them.
author: Andrew M.

description: Great place :) crew was nice and I left with full and happy belly :p everything was fresh and tasty
author: Radoslaw D.

description: I've been here a few times before and the food was good, though not as good as El Farolito. Sometimes I just don't want to wait in that line though and tonight was one of those nights. That was a mistake as I was very disappointed with my food. Ordered Chile Verde and I thought they gave me the wrong order. It didn't look our taste anything like it. Had a weird sour taste and had more giant chunks of fat than meat. I love the Chile Verde at Pancho Villa on 16th. Go there instead!
author: Dora L.

description:
I got a cheese enchilada and gave up eating it about half way through. The cheese is  gross. Guac is watered down. Salsa is bland. I ended up scraping off all the cheese and eating plain tortillas with rice and beans soaked in pico de gallo :( Now I have a stomach ache and I'm still hungry...

More importantly, I had a groupon type certificate for $10 off and the cashier told me her Manager had to verify certificates and wouldn't be back for several hours. She told me to try my certificate at McDonald's or Denny's... I proceeded to show her that it was specific to her restaurant and location to no avail. 

I'm sorry I gave them a chance....
author: Dharam K.

description:
Again, I think this is more of a meat-friendly place, but their veggie stuff is decent, and they have good salsa. If I remember correctly their veggie tacos should be measured in butt-tons - as in yeah, they're really big.  

Anther plus is that this place is clean. Overall, this is a pretty choice little spot.
author: Amber K.

description:
I'm going to be honest, the food isn't exactly the greatest in the world.  It's good and it definitely hits the spot, but that's not the reason I go here.  The reason I go here is because they're apparently cool enough to let a bunch of nerds take it over every Friday night to play board games, which is something insanely cool for a taqueria in the Mission to do.

The al pastor is really, really greasy, though.  It's manageable in a taco, but burritos just drip.

Recommended:
Carnitas burrito
Al pastor tacos
author: Norman S.

description: This is my go-to place when the line at El Farolito is long, and all I want is a massive super taco. It's massive, buried in meat, and covered in guacamole. I don't order anything else.
author: Donna H.

description:
Seemingly 
Solid 
super 
steak 
burrito

that got me sick last time  :(

Last tme, key word.

the end.
author: Athena S.

description: I love this place in Mission near 24th. Right off of the BART this place is awesome. Their burritos are as big as my arm and full of meat not just beans. The enchiladas are awesome and they have some of the best carnitas I have ever had. I eat here once a week it's so good. Check this place out its worth the trip.
author: John B.

description:
This is our go to late night munchies corner! There aren't that many places you can hit up at 4 AM after a night out, but I don't think this place actually closes. I also come here during the day, and it's always the same three guys working the place...hardest working people in SF.

The pico de gallo is to die for. Super spicy and yummy. My boyfriend always gets the super burrito and its huge and delicious. I'm a big fan of the carnitas tacos and the chile relleno.
author: Kexin C.

description:
The food is great although I felt like I was in a fast food restaurant. 
The service is like the one in a fast food restaurant, not very friendly. 
The ambiance is just cold and not very welcoming. 
If you just want to go to eat very good mexican food for a fair price, go.
I might return one day, but is definitely not the place I would go if I want to chill out while I eat.
author: Beatriz L.

description:
My first review after leaching off of this site for years. Just taking. No longer. And I present to you, on this monumentous occasion, the most under-appreciated taqueria in the Mission. Or this part of it at least. 

So, my one major barometer of a good taqueria are the tacos. duh; but specifically the carnitas and al pastor. They're widely available options for meat, so serve as a good standard order; also because they're generally delicious as well. These guys just consistently get both so right, so much so that "right" is now partially defined by their succulent benchmarks. Forget the lines down the block either way at La Taq or El Farolito, there's no wait at TSJ#1, and the pork is ready for you.
author: Hunter M.

description:
I ordered some food takeout here yesterday afternoon...a super taco with carne asada and a chile relleno plate. I had no idea there would be SO MUCH food in the box or I would have gotten just one or the other. But really I wanted both and didn't know the taco would be like 3 tacos. Anyway in the end I just ate the taco last night and then reheated the chile relleno today.

While I would not say this was the best I've ever had, in SF or elsewhere, it was good. As I've said, huge portions. I was thinking it was not quite as cheap as some of the other local taquerias, but once I saw the size of the portions I realized that it is very cheap indeed. The chips were really good and fresh. I liked the salsas. The meat was a little dry though.

One thing I was not crazy about (although I have to admit it tasted good when I reheated it in the oven today) was that they put the chile relleno in the microwave. I don't know if it was precooked and they were heating it up--more likely, I think, is that they were melting the cheese on top (I hope that's why) but that is still something I'd rather see done under a broiler than in a microwave when I'm eating out.  Again, it did taste good today, much better than many chile rellenos I've had (and I've had a lot)--very big, a lot of cheese--and the refried beans and rice were tasty (though the beans were a tad on the salty side for my taste). But I'm just not wild about seeing anything put in the microwave at a restaurant.

So...I guess I would recommend it as...not bad...but I'm sure there are better places too. I just moved here, so I will learn. The tacos I had at Cancun down the street in the Mission were amazing.
author: Jennie S.

description: I got the chicken quesadilla. I think I would have liked it better without the chicken. The good news is that the quesadilla was HUGE. The bad was that it was pretty unremarkable and not something I'd want to order again.
author: Emily F.

description:
Open late, amazingly huge portions, cheap, and quick. 

I usually get the quesadilla. I don't know how they do it, but this place seriously seems to put a whole block of mozzarella cheese into my 15" HUGE tortolla shell. It's a little bland, but I can go home and add stuff to it and still pay less than I would if I bought the tortilla and cheese myself. Plus it feels more authentic when it was made at a Mexican restaurant.
author: Georgette T.

description: I love these guys. I will definitely go out on a limb and say that their quality of ingredients, service, and overall care beats El Farolito TEN FOLD.  Being that I work near by, 7 days a week, I feel that I am a fairly good judge. Don't believe the hype. San Jose all the way. Super tacos and burrito plates, you cannot go wrong
author: andy s.

description:
This is a great alternative to Il Farolito if you want a midnight bite after a night of bar hopping and don't want to wait in the scary line at Il Faro.

I like that it's clean, spacious, and the only line is from the folks who can't stand the line at Il farolito's, haha.

I choose convenience over a miniscule bump in the taste of the food any day.
author: Ricky S.

description:
Best taqueria in the Mission in my opinion. The portions are huge and the salsa is much more fresh and delicious. I enjoy El Faralito like everyone else, but the salsa and carnitas are subpar compared to San Jose. 

I recommend anything with carnitas or the carne asada quesadilla. I've always had good experiences with the service as well. If you want a delicious taqueria that's open late with NO LINE, then try this spot out; it's right across the street from the 20 minute line of El Faro anyways.
author: David D.

description:
Taqueria San Jose is an old haunt of mine from my days living in the east bay, due to its proximity to BART and typical lack of line compared to the other local taquerias. Out of old familiarity, I ended up grabbing lunch here during my exhausting weekend of sublet searching.

It was pretty much as I remembered it from a couple of years back. This taqueria is more expensive than other taquerias but has less of a line, more space for eating, seems to generally be cleaner, and is open late. The food here isn't extroardinary, but I've never had any complaints. The portions are large - perfect for leftovers. There are more exciting options in The Mission for tacos and burritos, but this is a reliable place to hit up if you need to be fed in a hurry before catching BART.
author: Denise B.

description:
Been going here for a while after randomly selecting it while in the Mission one day. The food at this place is great. I have only tried the grilled chicken taco's and the burritos (GIGANTIC burritos), but they are both by far my favorites. The chicken has a little flavoring/seasoning that is not too much and not too little -- just right.

The longest line I have ever waited in here had 3 people in it ahead of me and the wait was no longer than 5 minutes. Note I have not been during "rush hour", but have been at many different times of day.

Would definitely recommend giving it a try.
author: John C.

description:
I ordered a burrito to go one afternoon and opened it during the late evening and didn't find my order. They mixed up the order for a vegatarian with avacado for a meat combo with PORK !
It was a couple of weeks before I went there again and they didn't express interest in "making good" ie sorry we got your order wrong !
I spoke with mr. Valle the owner the following day and he said something like come in again and we will give you what you paid for 
Again it was a couple of weeks before I came in again and the same guy didn't express interest in making amends for the error.
I spoke with mr. Valle on the phone again and he couldn't articulate in English a satisfactory response other than bring the wrong order.
Spent less than ten dollars and going to call it a write off !
author: A L.

description: I come here mostly for the friday night boardgame night.  The baby burritos are decent at $3 a pop which is almost full buritto size and does not come with rice.
author: Jessica P.

description:
This place is awesome.  I have fallen in love with the way they prepare the  chicken, and constantly have to fight the urge to get it in a quesadilla every time I go in there.  

The staff is super friendly, the server is really quick, and the place is much cleaner than it's 24th and mission rival across the block.  Something about standing in line in a packed house when I could be across the way in a cleaner place and watch ESPN while I wait, instead of drunks and crackfiends..

But the food is what brings me here!  Good stuff.
author: Jonathan B.

description: I heart this place.  Open late, never a big line unlike Faralito across the street, and huge portions with good reliable burritos (and great salsa).  Plus the guys play settlers of catan and other nerd games.  The real deal.
author: Hemant S.

description:
I love al pastor, and I loved the al pastor tacos at Taqueria San Jose!! I definitely could feel my arteries hardening as I watched the grease drip away from the taco remains clutched in my hand, but that is part of the experience, right? ;-)

My friends who didn't get al pastor (what were they thinking?!?) also were very, very happy with their selections.

I haven't tried Taqueria La Altena yet, but that's next on my list for al pastor tasting.
author: Andrew C.

description:
what i ordered... super burrito with carnitas

burrito was of an ok size, filling's were good as well but not much of the rice and guacamole or was there any? carnitas was very good.... so tender and spiced up right.

the real bad thing about my visit was the wait and that i asked for no beans and it was full of it (though it was tasty). i was about to return it but the lone cook was goin' bananas in the kitchen. c'mon two cashiers and one cook does not make any sense, greedy as owner/sbastards wan't to take your dough as fast as they could and could care less about their customers and/or their employees.

ambiance... so-so (spacious but dirty)
service...bad (take your money and go)
cost...$ (fair)
author: Gors P.

description:
Friendly staff, decent salsa  and a good late night burritos that gave me wonderful gas an indigestion for the rest of the night. The super burrito can easily be shared by 2 normal people. 

A good amount of seating and well lit.
author: Kat M.
