description: We had Taqueria San Jose baby breakfast burritos for the brunch the day after our wedding. They were delicious, ready on time, and affordable. Our guests loved having a taste of true San Francisco, and they're a perfect hangover cure.
author: Lindsay G.

description: On my last trek to Farolitos I parked in front of Taqueria San Jose. When I got back to my ride the sign on the front of TSJ stating they have the best Pastor in the city caught my attention. I accepted the challenge. I ordered one taco de Pastor. I have to say it was some of the best pastor I've ever had. And that's saying something. I try it everywhere. I can't speak on the rest of the menu. But if you are a pastor fan, I would call this a MUST TRY. Adios criticos de comidas.
author: Detox D.

description: These ppl don't honor their own gift certificates!! And it was NOT expired they just told me it was too large of a discount!! Wtf?!?! It was $15 off for a party of 4...we would have spent wayyyy more than that today. Their loss
author: Alyssa S.

description:
I'm used to those $1 tacos in Tijuana, but I guess you can't be picky about prices on this side of the border. I got 3 tacos for a little over $7, but these tacos were PACKED so full you couldn't even fold it up to eat it. So I ate half of the meat with my fork first and then folded it up. What a messy ordeal! Thank goodness for the bathrooms to wash up afterwards.

For my tacos I ordered tripe (very deep-fried and crispy), bbq pork (super oily), and fish (pretty meaty). They were all pretty good, but not anything super spectacular. The chips, however, were fantastic. They tasted like fresh corn tortilla chips. Not too salty like those store-bought ones. Their salsa was pretty good too.
author: Esther Y.

description:
I used to work on this block and I haven't ate there in 7 years.  I am not sure if this is still the case but there used to be two Taqueria San Jose's directly across the street from each other on this block.  All day long I would see employees bring stuff across the street back and forth.  Like a huge container of salsa in one of those big buckets.  Sometimes mops and misc. stuff.

Two restaurants with the same name right across the street from each other?  I found this to be very strange.  But bboth locations were yummy and this is the neighborhood for taquerias, so why not?

Low prices and good food.  Could be more clean and shiny inside.  Sometimes some shady customers.  Authentic Mission feel to the place complete with homeless person out front.

The prices are so good and the food is not the best, but damn good for the price, so i have to give it......four stars I guess.
author: Cynthia B.

description:
An overlooked gem next to the 24th St. BART station -- don't be fooled by the fact it's not as packed as the other places (which are just half its size).   Mileage varies when it comes to taquerias, but the delicious food is between Good and Terrific, and bonus convenience make this a solid 4 stars.

Succulent carne asada, spicy grilled chicken, weekend BBQ pork taco specials, and one of the most mouth-wateringly tangy green salsas in the Mission. (Yes I'm a local and get to make that judgement.) They even offer "baby burritos" if you're craving less than an whole donkey.

No doubt it lacks some critical ingredient of your favorite eatery. (Personally I always miss Cancun's grilled tortillas.) And San Jose humbly lurks in the giant late-nite shadow of Farolito across the intersection. But the food gives Farolito a run for their money, arrives in a fifth of the time, and you can enjoy it in a window seat or at a large table. (This place is huge = awesome for crowds.)

And man oh man, that green salsa!
author: Kimbro B.

description: Great late night taco.... very filling and tasty , place was empty around 10:30pm Thursday with only one guy working .... if there was a line you might have to wait .... either way would return for the tacos con pollo.
author: Sam B.

description:
The reddest taqueria ever. Red signs. Red interior. Lots and lots of red. And clean. Which is always a plus down in the good old Mission, especially at a burrito joint.

Prices are on the high side (especially for the breakfast burrito, but at least they made it happen with egg whites), so really your best bet is the baby burrito. Packed with meat and none of that distracting rice, for $3 and change it's the way to go.

Edible. Satisfying. And very red.
author: Jason B.

description:
It could have been the post NYE drunkeness or that the food was really good. I can't remember. Either way, the vegetarian tacos were hitting the spot!!

I wouldn't come all the way out here to try their food again, but if I was in the area and drunk, I might grab some tacos.

My only concern was the dead roach on the wall next to the table I was sitting. If I weren't drunk and busy stuffing tacos down my throat, I might have thought twice about eating there. My BF's response when I told him about the roach: "Well, it is the Mission." Touché.
author: Joshua C.

description:
If you love fish tacos, this place is very good and very affordable. The tacos have lots of tender tilapia and you can get four for $5.00. (There about) 

I have another favorite restaurant that I go to for steak tacos but they cost a lot more. I always come here for fish or when I have very little money. 

You can eat a super healthy and delishious  fish dinner here for very cheap!
author: Sandra W.

description:
What do you do when it's after 2:30a, the alcohol buzz waning to a quiver, yet you're hungry for just about anything, and not willing to wait in a 30 minute El Farolito line in the cold? You head to what's open - and for us that was Taqueria San Jose.

Bright with fluorescent lighting, smelling of cooked meats, this is the antithesis of the bar/club you just vacated. Luckily the bathrooms are clean (customer use only, and opened by a buzzer from the cashier), and the restaurant spacious, to accommodate revelers looking for a last meal. 

We quickly ordered some waters (a la Costco bottles), and our standard Quesadilla Suiza ($7.99). Like most places in the Mission, these quesadillas are enormous - hefty in weight, it is filled with meat, sour cream, lettuce, tomato, cheese, and some sauce - all wrapped in a tortilla and grilled. They serve it in 2 halves b/c it won't fit otherwise. It's delicious and hits the spot.

TSJ's version is a little lighter on the seasoning and the grilling (vs. EF) but it was still good. And they even accommodated AL's tradeout for a crisper taco shell. I did venture a bite of the Burrito Lengua. Have to say that it was too full of sour cream and personally not a fan of beef tongue. (The bumps gross me out.)

A clean decent alternative to waiting in the cold.
author: Cindy W.

description:
Stopped in for a burrito on my way home from work, seemed like kind of a long wait since I was the only customer. I got a carnitas burrito and asked for salsa verde, but pretty sure I ended up with some other kind of salsa. I think there were carrots in my rice which was weird, and some very raw onion which was so strong I couldn't finish the burrito. The carnitas were waaaay overcooked, to the point of being crispy and I got a big bite of something that I hope was only gristle. Too grossed out to finish. 

The photos on the wall looked good, I'd maybe come back and try the tacos since I can see whats in / on them. Wouldn't get carnitas ever again though.
author: Beth D.

description:
I ordered the al pastor and carnitas tacos as well as fish and chicken enchiladas. 

The tacos were well priced, flavorful and loaded with meat. There is also a fresh salsa bar which was nice.  There pico de gallo was very fresh and complimented the taco well.

The enchiladas were ok- not my favorite. The rice was very bland. It's not a bad choice in the Mission- just not the best. If it was just on the tacos I would have given it 4 stars but the enchiladas and the ambiance (or lack there of) knocked it down.
author: Mister Chub S.

description: It's the a giant place, it's open late, it's good, and it accepts card. I'm coming here instead of El Farolito. I don't think it's as good? Yes that's an intentional question mark, I only come to these taquerias late at night after a night of drinking and one greasy mexican place tastes the same as another when I'm hammered.
author: Rohan D.

description:
3 stars for the tasty food, 1 for the nice portions they give. Minus 1 star for their staff. My husband bit into some hard object, in his chicken taco which made his lip bleed. When we went to tell the woman about it, she called the manager/owner and he came over NOT apologizing but excusing himself. He went on about how it's not his fault. I told him all I wanted was to let him know in case it happens again. Granted, I think he was mostly afraid of a law suite since he mentioned twice about sending him the doctor's bill, he shouldn't have been so difficult as if we were attacking him. We told him several times we weren't going to go to the doctor's and we really just wanted to let them know. He ended up handing my hubby $30 bucks and told us to come back for a free meal. 

Food is great, kind of a weird experience though. But we will probably be going back (:
author: Yishra L.

description:
Okay, this place has officially gotten my thumbs up. Took a while, but it has totally grown on me. Mostly because the people that work here are so friggin awesome! 

Always friendly, hook a girl up with chips and lots of salsa cups. When I get home super late from work, a chicken taco with guac from this place hits the spot. Well cooked chicken and generous portions of both the protein and the guac.

Sounds like next time I need to try the fish taco. yum.
author: Allegra F.

description: CARNITAS!!! Great tacos. Their veggie super burrito is very good and isn't that 'heavy'. Service is quick, and they have all the essentials.
author: Conor B.

description:
another bowling night and mexican food right after... El Farolito was way too packed and was about to close in half an hour so we say this taqueria across the street.. we didnt really care anymore because we were hungry!!

we came in here, the place was much bigger, which is a plus, and the food is made pretty fast.

and again, in the middle of the night, its ghetto.. a lot of drunk people and whatever so its loud! but heck, i cant really say anything, were all out after a long night of partying or having fun..

the menu is sort of confusing because its mostly in spanish, theres english, but a lot of it was in spanish and i was confused! but i wanted good food lol

anyways, food is good, i feel kinda bad for the owners because everyone is so roudy, including us, but i think theyre used to it. hah!

theres a lot of sauces and condiments, yum!
author: Jessica C.

description:
Mmmm....I don't know what they marinate their meat with, but its damn good and makes for an excellent, filling burrito.

The salsa verde is also incredible.
author: Mark A.

description:
Went here for a chip and salsa craving after a night of drinking.  The chips were pretty standard, no different from the stuff you buy at the grocery store.  I still prefer the thin, warm homemade chips that they serve at my favorite mexican restaurant (La Pinata in Fremont).  Their red salsa was just ok, but I really liked the pico de gallo, which had a decent kick to it.  

They didn't bat an eye when we got a second order of chips (don't think they charged us), and kept going back to the salsa bar and refilling our chips, so kudos to them for that.

The place was pretty dead when we got there around midnightish, but had lots of people around 1am when we left.  It wasn't the best chips and salsa I ever had, but it was cheap and it hit the spot.
author: Arlene M.

description:
Okay, so it's been a while since I've ordered from here. I stopped eating burritos a while back since I cut back on eating a lot of carbs and would just grub on quesadilla suizas. I've been craving for a carne asada burrito the last couple of days, so I decided to stop by here since it was on my way home coming from BART. They've remodeled this place since I was here last and I have a feeling it was to compete for esthetic reasons, other than for customers, with Rosmunde next door. In any case,the place looks nice. The first thing I noticed was the new menu board and the new prices! YIKES!!! I always thought TSJ#1 was pricey compared to other taquerias, but come on! Then again, they just remodeled, so I figured they'd have to increase the prices a little. However, I wasn't expecting for them to skimp on some things.  

As I was waiting for my order, I decided to go to the salsa bar- what's with the small containers??  They weren't this small before, why start now??? After I got my order, I noticed no chips in the bag. I asked the guy, "What happened with the chips????" He said they were extra. WTF????? They weren't extra before. So he asked if I wanted to buy a bag. For $1.50, sure why not. At least he filled it to the top of the paper bag. Sheesh!! Anyway, the burrito was good, minus the sour cream. I didn't want everything in it, just meat, rice and salsa. I got that along with the sour cream and guac. It was still good. I ate half for lunch and the other half for dinner. Needless to say, I won't be coming back here if I get a craving for a burrito or quesadilla. I think I'll stick to my usual spot, which I won't mention =).
author: Neni E.

description:
This is my favorite Taqueria of all time.

Why?  Well, they say you always remember your first... and this was where I ate my first ever carne asada burrito, no frijoles!

Throughout high school, my friends and I always ate here.  When we were broke, we'd buy sodas and the guys working there used to give us chips and salsa.  A high school student's dream!

Also, the owner (I don't know if he's still the owner) used to have the funniest (unintentionally) business card ever - it said "Taqueria San Jose" and there was a drawing of the spit of meat... under which was his name, "David."  So we named the spit of meat David.  Good times!

While the new staff is a tad more abrasive and the ambiance is akin to a cafeteria, I still LOVE this place.  And the carne asada still rocks.
author: Melanie K.

description:
Visually appealing, with large, colorful murals of San Jose, but lacking yum yum.

The chorizo in the super tacos was depressing and the only hearty topping on the super nachos was sticky malaise.

Plus, every menu item is about a buck or two more expensive than other Mexican joints in the area.

I feel so empty.
author: Corbin C.

description: Taqueria San Jose has delicious, reasonably priced food. The restaurant was recently renovated, and the newly colorful walls enhance the attractive murals. On our numerous visits for lunch and dinner, the service has always been extremely fast, even when we've been there with a group. My husband's all-time favorite is their huge al pastor super burrito. Mine is the carne asada super taco. What's practically unique about Taqueria San Jose's super tacos is what's included -- one of these is a meal in itself. It starts with two soft corn tortillas. Meat (of your choice), cheese, beans, rice, guacamole, sour cream, and salsa are layered on top (there's also a salsa bar, so you can add your own). It's kind of like an open-faced burrito, but better because you can mix everything together, so every bite is enriched with guacamole, sour cream, and salsa! There are separate bathrooms for men and women, and they're clean and modern.
author: Karen M.

description:
After a wild Friday night adventure at Club Six, I worked up quite the appetite. Richard G. recommended this place based on my affinity for carnitas. I was not disappointed. 

I was impressed.

This place is located across the street from the super awesome La Taqueria, which recently shut down in San Jose due to the owner wanting to retire. It still exists in SF and it thrives; yet, Taqueria San Jose can find a way to compete with the best taqueria ever?

How do they do it? Well, by making the best carnitas in town and staying open late.

Wow. Holy smokes. My super burrito was pricey (over $8), but it was also enough for 2 people. I could not finish it. Everything was fresh and the carnitas were amazing. 

Ajua! Ajua!

I'll be telling my friends and even my future kids about them. Well, as long as I survive the swine flu.

My fellow Yelpers (Richard G., Yvonne C. and Jessica Y.) were growing tired, so they made me eat faster. So I just took a fork to my burrito and scooped out the remaining carnitas and shoved them down my throat.

Heaven wrapped in a tortilla. Heaven on a fork. 

I also tried their chicken quesadilla when Jessica was not looking. It was very tasty and they did not use garbage boiled chicken (like they do at La Victoria). 

Anyway, if you are ever in San Francisco and you have a late night craving for Mexican grub, you have to consider Taqueria San Jose. 

I dare you try to the carnitas.

Heaven wrapped in a tortilla.

Heaven in my mouth.

Heaven in my tummy.

Heaving in the toilet.

Ajua! Ajua!
author: Archie G.

description: I've since tried the carnitas (pork) and the fish fillet, both of which are really good. The pork is juicy and has crunchy bits and the fish is flaky and has a really tasty spice rub on it.
author: Paul L.

description: This was the 1st taqueria I ever ate at in SF 20 years ago and used to be my favorite. I always loved their Carnitas Burritos and I had two in the past 6 weeks to give them a chance before writing this review. Can you say FREEZER BURN? My guess is that their freezer went out, they had a big giant piece of pork that partially thawed and they refroze it.  They served me freezer burned pork twice and I'm 100% sure as we all know what freezer burned food tastes like. I'm not sure if their other meat is freezer burned but if you must eat there, stay away from the pork!
author: Russell R.

description:
A good value for the price, because dang! that's a lot of food. I had the carne asada and felt like I should have been rolled out the door and through the Mission (but how can you say no to such deliciousness?).

My BFF is my resident go-to gal on all things authentically Mexican (she is  of Mexican heritage and she has lived there, nuff said).  When we walked into this place she seemed to approve and after we got our order (and after she made fun of me for asking if they had HOR-chata) she tucked in to her tacos and I waited for her assessment.  Very rarely does she give the green light on authenticity, but said even though they were missing pineapple from the dish she was eating, it was legit (hurray!).

We spent the better portion of the hour stuffing our faces in relative peace (weeknight) listening to a strange mix of songs ranging from 50's rock/soul and traditional mariachi music. The price didn't really faze me - I've seen much worse and to me it's worth it to pay a little extra for something tasty.
author: Marissa C.

description:
You should go here.  They have multiple "best of" awards on the wall, but they are WAY too humble about it.  These people are SO nice and gracious.  

The al pastor is the very best.  And if you don't think so, you're only out $2.40 for a taco!  I LOVE you, TSJ!  See you soon!
author: Amy D.

description:
I have to agree with Colin H. 
I used to love this place when I first started going there. Now, all they offer me (aside from pretty good tacos de el pastor) is a big ass Corona for like $8. 
You have to realize that by gentrifying your taqueria, you're going to lose a lot of your true fan base, and probably even some hipsters too.
author: J A.

description: Very prompt service.  I had beef tongue tacos.  The portions were generous and the taste incredible.  I'll definitely be back.
author: Rex C.

description:
My search for the holy grail of crispy fish tacos led me to the mecca of taquerias, the intersection of 24th and Mission, home to El Farolito. Although I've enjoyed a number of offerings from El Farolito, sadly, they don't offer pescado tacos. So down the block I spied Taqueira San Jose and thought I'd give it a go. 

I ordered two crispy pescado tacos and one super pescado taco, and chips and salsa. It's almost criminal when a taqueria charges for chips and salsa. Chips were so-so, but the self serve salsa was on FIRE. And I am not usually one to shy away from spicy fare. It hurt in an oh so good, hit you in the back of the throat, need another Mexican coke kind of way. I suppose $1.50 for chips and salsa isn't going to kill me, and yet I will grumble anyways. 

On to the tacos: My mistake for ordering them to go, and not devouring them on the spot. But minus one star for the craptastic packing. By the time I got to unwrapping them, my crispy tacos had been reduced to some crumbled soggy bits of corn meal mush hugging what I supposed was the fish. My anticipation deflated, and I was sorely disappointed.

I was somewhat cheered by Pookie's selection of the super taco. A taco so laden with rice, beans, salsa, guac, sour cream and seasoned fish, that it had to be packed in its own little take out box. Pookie even noted that it was "damn heavy" and "are you sure this is just one taco?" We ended up downing this one with a fork, since it didn't led itself to the fine art of taco origami, and probably would fall apart at first bite. 

A little pricey for tacos, at around $4 each. I think El Farolito is a super cheap $1.95.

The Good: Bottom line, the pescado WAS delish, and the super taco was pretty amazing. My MO next time would be to order the super pescado taco CRISPY and eat it right there as it came out of the kitchen. An added plus? They take credit/debit cards, so you're not fumbling for cash at the end of a looooong night. 

The Bad: Shitty packing ruined my crispy taco, and I ended up eating it with a fork and chips. Also, paying for chips and salsa makes me feel violated.
author: Zehra A.

description: I only came here because the line at El Farolito was too long and I had to catch a BART train.  After eating my burrito, I am quite pleased the line was too long across the street.  My burrito was a little more expensive to get the guac and cheese added to it then it would be elsewhere, but boy, did they pack on the meat in this one.  Aside from the top and bottom of this bad boy, every bite was packed with morsels of meat.  It held up warm and it held up three hours later on my plane.  I grabbed three different salsas and each was on point as dressing for my side of chips (Hallelujah for them not being stale).  I could have wished for more guacamole, but overall this was a solid burrito and something I may wish to bring on every flight I take out of SFO.
author: Jeremy G.

description: A decent burrito with no rice so it's less filling. Fresh guacamole is great and the carnitas is excellent. The crisp taco is good too. Ridiculiously large and that green salsa is nice.
author: Scott M.

description:
In my quest for the perfect al Pastor, I finally made my way here. I found my quest will continue, and will still go to El Gran Taco Loco when I want this greasy, sometimes spicy pork. 

My roommate was hungry for a burrito. After first going to Phat Philly, while waiting for the 14, I went here. It's clean at least. She reported her burrito to be just OK. 

For lunch for myself the next day, I bought a quesidilla suiza with al Pastor. I also thought it was just OK, and nothing special. Perhaps all the good reviews were alcohol enhanced? 

I did like the salsa though. But I don't think I will be back.
author: Michael M.

description: First of all I'm a native San Franciscan who uses to frequent this place years ago.  Decided to grab a taco and quesadilla the other day.  Yes the decor and atmosphere has taken a turn for the good.  But your not eating decor.  The taco was full of whole beans and the meat tasted like low quality.  The quesadilla was big and salty. Im very disappointed in the food.  Not at all like I remember.  Can't believe how pricey it is now.
author: Joselyn C.

description: I had the beef enchilada here, I wasn't really blown away by the taste but it was a pretty good sized enchilada and unlike some of the other places they don't charge extra for the chips they include them with your order.
author: Nicholas A.

description: A pretty decent super with carnitas. It was above average(if only slightly.) Nothing about the ambiance here is worth sticking around for unless you get a beer and have too. There's a game night on Mondays, which maybe needs a separate review, but in case you were thinking about going for that I don't recommend it. I tend to judge burritos pon size, but this one was also relatively fresh.
author: Nik K.

description:
This place fucking BLOWS. I'll tell you what, I'm sitting here, right now, eating the burrito I got there and I can hardly finish it. 
I asked for chicken. The gem behind the counter said 'grilled or shredded' (Personality of a corpse, this one), I said I wanted shredded chicken. I said 'oh, by the way, can I get extra sour cream on the side?'. What did I get? A burrito with NO CHICKEN and sour cream INSIDE. This burrito is cold and flavorless. Did I mention I paid almost TEN DOLLARS for this shit?

I live a block away from this place and this is the first time I've been there.  I suppose next time I will not be lazy and walk the extra block for El Farlitos
author: Alexandra F.

description:
My friend tried to get me to go here recently which I had to decline don't get me wrong once upon a time this was the place to be after 2am. I knew all the people who worked here and after hanging out on 30th and Mission( at the gas station) or Day Street Park we would come and eat our drunk away.

Even when I stopped hanging out outside I would come after the clubs that is until that one fateful experience.

I was eating my burrito and everything was all good until I reached for a chip and out popped a COCKROACH as big as day I could not belive it...

My Late night burrito Dreams shattered...
author: Kim R.

description:
Much like mediocre sex, life is too short for mediocre burritos.

Even at 2 in the morning.
author: Jess T.

description:
oh god.  meat on a vertical spit.  When you see that pillar of meat and fat, slowly turning as the heating elements spark and flare from fat melting and sputtering on the grill, you know you're at a place to be reckoned with.  They have it at truly med.  they have it at el castillito.  and they have it here.

I was walking past 24th and mission and was hungry and el farolito had their usual massive line, so I kept walking and there was taqueria san jose, which burritoeater talks well of, as do other yelpers.  No line!  sweet.

One glance at the spit and I knew what I had to order.  dos tacos.  un de pastor, y un de carnitas.  carnitas and pastor.  the pillars of mexican pork.

tacos were 2.40 ea (inc tax), and the pile of meat was bigger than the tortillas they came on.  I picked up the taco de pastor first and the meat fell all over the basket, as the hot taco burned my hand.  I shoved a bite in my mouth, and it was just heaven.  I'd have to say the pastor at castillito is more flavorful, but I think perhaps the balance here was better, since the "bbq" flavor was not overpowering.  I'm going to need to come back a few more times to do the true comparison.  

The carnitas...came out looking like pork hash browns on a tortilla.  oh man.  PORK HASH BROWNS.  absolute genius.  it was a patty of stranded pork, with a whole side browned and crispy.

Dare I say the carnitas was better than farolito's?  I dare.

damn, I think I have a new default taqueria in this part of the mission.

only complaint:  the pico de gallo needed some more tomato.  it was nice that it had lots of pickled jalapenos chopped up in it, but still.
author: Fong L.

description: Amazing service, amazing food, and a very clean establishment. I've been going to Taqueria San Jose for the past 4 months and I'm still not tired of it. Their quesadilla suiza ($7.99), in my opinion, is probably the best in the Mission! The carnitas platter is also out of this world. I would definitely recommend Taqueria San Jose over any other Mexican place in the Mission.
author: Justen P.

description:
Have you ever been drunk in the Mission?
Have you ever been hungry after your alleged "drunken night" in the Mission?
Have you ever craved a taco, burrito or nachos after bar time?
Have you ever been appalled at the line that wraps around the corner outside El Farolito at 2am?

Refusing to wait over an hour for a $2 taco you stumble caddy corner across the street into Taqueria San Jose.  Damn, it's bright in here... you wish you brought your sunglasses, but there's no line and it's clean enough.  You order your taco and a quesedilla and within 5 minutes it appears before your half-lidded, drooling, smiling face.  You inhale your meal within a matter of seconds and pity all those SUCKAS *still* waiting in the rain just to order their food.
author: Shayna N.

description: One of my favorite Taqueria's. Their Carne Asada is flavorful as well as their Carnitas. They're a little pricey but I feel like I've paying for quality. The main reason I go here is because I LOVE LOVE LOOOOVE their Cantalope Juice. I come in quite frequently to just pick up their juice. It's YUMMY! Their servers also give you free chips and salsa & hand deliver your order to your table. Been going here since a child & I won't be stopping anytime soon.
author: Dessa S.

description:
Gross.  I don't care how many cocktails and cheap beer I've thrown back.  I would rather eat my own regurgitated dinner than go here again.
I went with a group of friends after hitting a few bars, e.g. I was boasting a significant enough buzz to enjoy most anything put in front of me.  However, my order of cheese enchiladas was hard, stale, and more than a little mysterious.  My friend, who ordered the chicken burrito, was met with chicken so undercooked that it was pinker than the bubblegum stuck under the table.  The others, who actually chose to eat their food, were all met with a very uncomfortable visit from the 'rhea fairy later that night... if you catch my drift.
author: Christine M.

description: Best al pastor super burrito in the universe.  I live in San Luis Obispo county and always make it a point to stop and grab a burrito when I'm in the city.  I'd dare you to find a better burrito anywhere.
author: Simon L.

description:
I can't really comment much on whether their burritos are mediocre, but until I visited this place on a Friday night at 2 in the morning, I was convinced that NorCal just couldn't do tacos the way SoCal did.  This discovery was nothing short of miraculous.  (Sorry, NorCal...but it is what it is.)

I had the al pastor super taco, or taco supreme...or whatever the taco with all the fixings was, and you should try it too.
author: Dwigt S.

description: Great tacos! I had some alpastor, tripitas and carne asada. The meat was tender and had great flavor for the alpastor and asada. The tripitas were nice and crispy as they should be. I will definately return here again.
author: Lulu G.

description:
Clean.  Crisp.  Refreshing.  Ahhhh.  Sounds like a beer commercial, right?  right?  Wrong!  I'm talking about Ceviche tostadas!  Just because the name of the place tells me to buy a taco, I have the freedumb to choose anything on the menu.  Plus, on a hot day in the Mission, towards the end of our "1st annual Taqueria Crawl", a great ceviche is something you should not pass up.  Of course, their name also implies that we are in another city, but I'll let it slide.
Location: good.  very close to Mission and 24th.  Near lots of bus stops, pedestrians, bicyclists, homeless, hipsters (i can't escape!), and of course Mexicans.  
Atmosphere: big, bright, quiet and loud at the same time, busy, very clean, so clean in fact the whole place smelled like pine sol and bleach and fresh cilantro.  
Crazy:  a lady came out of the restroom yelling at us cuz she thought we threw a bunch of  baby wipes in the sink.  Well, we didn't do it.  She said "we gotta keep it clean in here!"  Then she kept yelling and the cooks finally looked over at her, so I retorted, "Shut up you old hag!" (in Spanish) and waved her to leave the place.  She had enough and left.  The whole place cheered.
Food:  Great tacos al pastor, cut right of the vertical spit, ask for pineapple and easy on the salsa-- makes it too runny.  It's good!  But on the side or less is fine with me.  Like I said before, the tostada was really really nice.  Perfect mix of lime, fish, onion, everything.  They give you big avocado slices on it too.  mmmmmmmmmmmmmm.
Price:  a little bit expensive for tacos, but everything else is standard.  
Professional Opinion: A good, authentic choice amongst a sea of worthy opponents.  Cheaper tacos elsewhere.  At least here, you know everything is clean if that matters to you.  If not, just eat the scraps on the floor outside.
Provecho.  Goce de su alimento
author: Joshua K.

description:
I went here last weekend and I am STILL craving it!!   i didnt even look at the menu, i just asked for a "big shrimp burrito".
They made it and brought it out to me (gave me some delicious chips first).  OMG it was soooooo goooood!!  Full of big shrimp, rice, beans, sour cream, guac, and super fresh tomatoes.  The best part about it was the tortilla. 
The tortilla was so soft and delicious!
I am still totally craving the burrito here!  They are friendly too.

And the bathroom was nice and clean.
author: Bettie P.

description:
Im a huge burrito fan and Im generally content with any burrito you put in front of me but this place failed to satisfy my craving. These are the kind of burritos where u cant tell what's inside and every ingredient tastes the same- like one big mush inside a tortilla. The most disturbing part is it's impossible to tell if they gave you the chicken you ordered or some sort of mystery meat. 

Don't waste your time here - go across the street to La Taqueria instead.
author: Rachel B.

description: Just a quick hope from the 24th Mission Bart station. They fill your burrito with lots of rice, so much that it's overflowing. It's definitely a decent deal...the regular burrito was almost like a super in most places. The staff were pretty nice. It's a decent place to eat if you're in the area, but I'd probably go somewhere else if I had a choice.
author: Amy J.

description:
For some reason this location is not nearly as good as their Mason Street Taqueria #3. 

The burritos are a bit runnier and a bit more salty than at thier #3 counterpart. Too many good taquerias in the Mission to bother with this one. Go across the street to El Farollito and save Taqueria San Jose for when you are in the North Beach area.
author: Drue C.

description:
Just a quick precursor... I just visited Mexico two weeks ago and experienced the best tacos I've ever set my tongue upon.

I have yet to experience "the Mission" and the legendary food in the district. No better place to start than Taqueria San Jose. 

I ordered 3 tacos: carne asada, pollo abodado and carnitas. Just to get a taste of all they had to offer. I have to admit, they give you a TON of meat, a welcomed surprise :) The pollo abodado was okay but the carne asada was not very good. The carnitas though... was absolutely delicious! The pieces of meat were nice and crispy on the outside and moist and juicy on the inside. YUM!

The chips they included kinda threw me off. They're the circular kind you find in the supermarket :/ wasn't sure what to make of them. 

They have a small assortment of salsas, just the bare necessities. The prices were okay... $2.12 for each taco.
author: Danvin R.

description:
One Heaven of a Fish Taco 

Ok, silly title aside, WOW! Our 13 year old neighbor recommended this one and I'll tell you, that kid is going places with taste buds like that. 

To top it all off it's only $2.50. The fish is grilled not breaded. Not that i would kick a good breaded fish taco out of bed either. (cough) El Matate ( end cough) 

I absolutely love the people who work there as well, always happy and they always remember my order. There's a gum ball machine you can hit up on the way out too;) 

And don't forget to get some of that sweet sweet Strawberry Water.
author: Chantelle T.

description:
Taqueria San Jose is the Mission's overlooked treasure.

Seriously, best Taqueria in town, and i know of which I speak.

Yeah, they're super burrito's are a bit pricey, but they are twice the size of the one's at La Taqueria and 3 times as tasty. 

The real treat at San Jose are their carnitas.  I know my carnitas.  I really do, and these are the best in town.  Crispy on the outside, chewy on the inside, no fat chunks like at other places.  They throw the carnitas on the grill and crisp them to order.

If you're tight on cash, you can go in and get two carnitas tacos (served with free chips, they dont charge like other places) and be full and happy.  Oh, make sure you get the salsa verde on those free chips as it is BOMB.

Yeah.  So stop wasting your time in line at Farolito or your money at La Taqueria and treat yourself to some San Jose.
author: Tom T.

description:
Since I couldn't bike home after doing my part to finish a pitcher of Sangria at Cha Cha Cha...we went on a hunt for food in the Mission on a late Sunday night.

We ended up at Taqueria San Jose and picked up a couple of steak burritos since apparently stuffing ourselves with fried and fatty Cuban Tapas didn't inflict enough damage on our arteries.

The steak was good and the burritos were on the moist end, but that worked well here. I don't remember the salsa blowing me away here, but overall an excellent late night stop.

Good seating available inside (maybe 1-1.5 size of a starbucks) and there is a bike rack within a building or two of the restaurant.
author: Varun ..

description:
The underdog of 24Th and Mission. I fucks with San Jose a lot. It's way better than overrated as fuck La Taqueria which is for people who think salsa is exotic. I fuck with Farolito too but I ride for San Jose. yeah the chips are those generic lame joints you find all over the city but if you're going to a taqueria for fucking nachos then you need to take your ass back to taco bell.  But man when they step up they got the game on lock. One late morning I showed up and got some Al Pastor that fucking killed anything I'd eaten anywhere else. I'd had Al Pastor from here before but the morning is the jump off for the al pastor. The carnitas are dope too. I usually get the plate for those or grab a couple of tacos. basically just stick to the pork cause they know how to rock that shit. Although the lengua here is tasty also.

I don't know what kind of softhands are asking for non spicy tacos because you can't get a fucking spicy taco in San Francisco.
author: Sergio O.

description:
I was here during the Street Food Festival. It took us 1 hour for them to make the food we ordered. Not even kidding. 

They took tons of orders even though they knew they wouldn't be able to serve people food for an hour. I think they got a little greedy seeing all the business come in. Needless to say, an angry mob formed. The poor guy in the back seemed really stressed out, and with good reason. 

After an hour I was starving so I asked for a refund. They asked what my number was and proceeded to go back and make it. I would have felt bad, but it was 3PM by that time and I'd had no lunch that day. They also decided to make to-go orders first, but that meant that none of the orders that were "for here" got made. Some people had been there even longer than an hour!

When the food came, it wasn't very good. I had the tacos, and I had indigestion and foul belches all afternoon. Pretty poor experience there. With all the great burrito places in the Mission, I don't think I'll be back. I do realize others like this place a lot, but I was really disappointed.
author: Jay S.

description:
Was excited to go back to this place. I remember having tried it about a year ago after the Dia De Los Muertos celebration. I seemed to remember it was good. 

Well, we went back last saturday and it was OK. I order tacos: 1 al pastor, 2 lengua, and one carne asada. The al pastor was tasty, but overly oily. The lengua was gross, over cooked, big chuncks and smelled gamey. Yuck! You've got to steam the cow tonque carefully, the meat should be tender and fall apart ;-) The carne asada was probably the best of the bunch.

The search for the best taqueria continues. I maybe back for a burrito. As I said before, some places aren't good at tacos, but make great plates and burritos. These are my people man, I believe in giving second chances ;-)
author: isaias J.

description:
It was Saturday morning and I was really craving watermelon aguas frescas, accompanied by a super burrito.  I went to 4 or 5 taquerias/tortas places, and no watermelon aguas frescas was to be found.  Taqueria San Jose had cantaloupe, and I'd never been there before, so I figured why not.

The decor has the requisite murals depicting life in the Mexican desert, and a jukebox was playing Mexican hits as you expect in the Mission.

A large cantaloupe aguas frescas and an al pastor super burrito set me back around $13.  Chips are pretty standard, mass-produced but good.  The salsa bar was good and they have Tapatio on the tables.. nice!

The burrito was enormous, but not all that great.  I mean, it wasn't bad, the al pastor was decently marinated but doesn't compare to El Farolito across the street.  The rest of the ingredients were pretty standard.

I enjoyed the cantaloupe aguas frescas, but I think the stuff at La Taqueria (also across the street) is better.

Overall, this place is ok, but La Taqueria and El Farolito are better, giving you little to no incentive to eat here.
author: Joseph N.

description:
Could be the best taco's in SF.   Yep, i said it.  Al Pastor, Pollo are my favs.
Of course, best tacos and best burritos can get religious, so i'll just leave it at that.

Been coming here for 12 years, mostly late night snacks but also good for lunch and dinner.   Love the free chips and salsa bar.   And the jukebox and colorful clientele at 2am.
author: chad n.

description:
Looking to change things up a bit, my girlfriend and I decided to try a "new" (the last time I ate at Taqueria San Jose was when The Fugees were on tour with the Roots, which was a long time ago, as in 1996) taqueria in the Mission. Our choices: Taqueria Cancun (the one between 18th and 19th) and Taqueria San Jose. Since I didn't feel like driving through a goddamn hurricane for tacos, we settled on the one that is closest to my house.

I hadn't been back to my stomping grounds for a while (Luna Park definitely does not count), and I quickly saw that it was the same as I had left it. There were roughly 5 or 6 police cars all over this stretch of Mission street, sirens blaring and a mass of cops walking around like one of them had lost their keys. As we crossed the street in the rain, we passed by two police offers, who quickly ran down the situation:

Cop 1: "So we still don't have a victim?"
Cop 2: "That's right, Lieutenant."

Nothing like tacos and random gunfire to welcome you home.

Taqueria San Jose, as you might of guessed, is a 3-star taqueria that doesn't really have anything to write home (or on Yelp) about. The food is a bit greasy, the salsa at the salsa bar is not fresh, and the place is cold as shit. However, sometimes you kind of want that, or dare I say need that. I ordered 3 carne asada tacos with cheese and guacamole, and they were both great. Not taco truck great, not La Taqueria great, but "it's 11pm and I'm glad I'm eating these tacos instead of gnawing my fucking arm off from hunger" great. And that's all you can really ask for.

With so many taquerias in the area, why chose Taqueria San Jose over any other taqueria? Well, if it's 1:30 AM and you want to a) eat your food sometime within the next hour, and b) avoid the drunk jackass scenesters at El Farolito, this place is just across the street.
author: Alexis C.

description:
I love love love Mexican food. There are so many places with so many varieties, eventually you might ask: 'Is this really Mexican?' How should I know? I have not even been south of the US border. So now that you know you are dealing with a Gringa, here is my review. 

Yum. And I have had better. Maybe next time I will order something different than the burrito, maybe some tacos, which my friend Sally liked.
author: Betsy W.

description:
For starters, this place is expensive compared to El Farolito across the street, and El Farolito tastes better also. 

I went here about a month ago and got a quesadilla suiza, mine was cool, nothing too spectacular. My friend had a pork quesadilla and it was THEE greasiest thing ive ever witnessed in my life. The entire quesadilla had turned pink from the grease. I may have a picture of it around here somewhere.

Yuck.
author: D F.

description:
The first stop on our taco crawl.  Had chips and red snapper tostada.  Chips were great, guac was a little off (too spicy?), tostada was great.

The place itself is roomy, slightly shady, but definitely has a good "family owned and operated" feel.  (whether that's true or not I have no idea).  Beer was $5+tax which was a little high for the area, but a solid stop nonetheless.
author: DH H.

description:
Taqueria San Jose in the city?? Yes, its true... I would hate to say it.. but I still love La Vics.. maybe only for their sauce... we came here after a random night at Bruno's... our friend said that this place was pretty good and after I had that bacon wrapped hotdog at the corner... I didn't think anything else could've tasted any better.. 

A super burrito is $7.99.. which is pretty pricey in my opinion... if they had some special type of sauce here.. I would have to say one of the best burritos I've had.. not only because I was a bit drunk..  if we're ever in the area.. I'll have to try their tacos next time!
author: Liz L.

description: The veg burrito was subpar, the burrito was missing something.  I just felt like I was having a bundle of tortillas. Plus the salsas were ok. I had to rate it as the worst veg burrito I have had in the Mission.
author: Ajesh S.

description:
I've been coming here since 1994, and I've always loved it.
It doesn't change much, and the tacos and burritos are great.
I like ordering tongue and "head meat" (buche?), and they're always delicious so don't be afraid to try.
author: Tom S.

description: Eh, definitely not the best burrito in the Mission. My carnitas burrito was decent but my friends chicken burrito was bone dry- tons of extra salsa was needed to add flavor to it. With El Farolito one block away, I don't see much need to come back here.
author: David D.

description: Large (almost too large to eat in one sitting), yummy burrito for 8 bucks.  Would have been 4 stars, except the guacamole wasn't that fresh.
author: Danny C.

description: The Taco Crawl crew hit Taqueria San Jose on crawl #1 (Dec 2004).  The crowd of 20-odd taco eaters was unanimous in its disapproval.  So many tacos and so little time to waste here...
author: Laurence W.

description:
Let's go with 3.5 stars...
I love tacos!
First taco- one with just carnitas and guacamole- the meat was over flowing and the guacamole was fresh.  It was the perfect taco! And I was able to eat it like a regular taco.
Second taco- chicken super taco.  It was a bit much...it was like a messy burrito.  There was no way I would be able to eat it like a regular taco, so it should be called a tostada with a soft shell.  The chicken was cool- a bit too over spiced, lots of rice, beans, cheese, hot salsa, sour cream, and guacamole.  It was huge - I had to leave over half of my taco/tostada:( I'll so be back for the carnitas! 
Another plus to make it a 3.5- they accept atm/credit cards- perfect when I'm short of cash!
author: Valarie A.

description:
Taqueria San Jose should be one of your two destinations when 2AM rolls around (other being Taqueria Cancun). The taqueria is an open dining room complete with jukebox with lots of Mexican selections. I had a carne asada super burrito and it was great. The meat tasted really good. Around 2AM, the line gets pretty long. Out the door long. We were able to beat the crowd so I could get a chance to take in the food. 

Overall, the experience was pleasant.
author: Andrew Y.

description: Look- anyone that serves good ceviche i'm a fan of, especially at a very resonable price $2.50 um, yeah I will have two orders please,  my co worker had a burrito that looked bigger than him! Great prices and the food here is real good. My co workers and I make the effort to catch BART and eat here when we are in the mood for Mexican food and I am having a ceviche craving. It's right around the corner from 24th and mission BART station.
author: X X.

description:
I went here once a few weekends ago late at night. I was less than impressed with my chicken burrito. I can't explain it very well but the ratios of meat to other ingredients was off somehow. The meat itself didn't taste that good either. It was very dry chicken that seemed like it had been over BBQed. Maybe I just got a bad batch, but I've had quite a bit better.

I would suggest many other taquerias in the Mission over this place.

The only advantage I found was that this place wasn't as busy at 1:30am compared to the overly popular competing taqueria kitty corner across the street, which seems to attract all the after bar/club hipster crowd. 

If I remember correctly, the prices were decent-- around what you would normally pay for a mission burrito.

Overall, it's probably a 3 star if I went back and tried it multiple times, but from my 1 time there, I wasn't very pleased and didn't even finish my whole burrito-- something I almost never do.
author: P. D.

description:
Super-Burrito.. Carnitas... standard fare for me. V. friendly workers, and v. tasty buritto. 

I'd come back (but probably won't b/c Taqueria Cancun is just down the block)
author: Mike S.

description:
This place gets a one star upgrade because it's open late.

Wandering home at 3:30 am this weekend I was in dire need for a burrito. Farolito's line was too long so I ran, wait stumbled over to San Jose and ordered a super carne asada burruito.  It hit the spot but I realized I probably would have been happier at Farolitos.
author: Adam L.

description:
I had a hard time deciding how many stars to give this place. Let me explain. 

The Al Pastor here is outstanding... in the traditional divey taqueria way. It's nice and spicy, and the ample grease mixes with sour cream to form some sort of heavenly goo. 

Some people in the area (and the dudes on burritoeater.com) will claim that Taqueria Can-Cun and Taqueria San Francisco have better Al Pastor. Let me break it down like this: 

- San Jose has what I've come to expect from great Al Pastor. It's spicy. It's greasy. It has a few little crunchy burned pieces. It has a ton of flavor, and is downright satisfying.

- Can-cun's Al Pastor often has the same qualities I described above. Other times, I get a load of Al Pastor there that's *too* *damn* *sweet*. Weird. It's ok, but it tastes mostly like paprika and brown sugar.

- Taq. San Francisco is in its own world. I can't exactly compare their Al Pastor to others just yet, because it isn't what I'm used to. It's not all that greasy, and there are no burned pieces. The quality control is actually outstanding, and it's definitely delicious. It's just that I feel like I'm eating something else... not quite Al Pastor. I do love it, though, whatever it is. I have to go back again.

The grilled chicken at Taq. San Jose kinda tastes like the Al Pastor... spicy, but not so greasy. 

Choosing either the chicken or the Al Pastor will result in a solid burrito experience. 

They have good salsa, too, and their pickled carrots and peppers are delicious.

Everything else here is kinda mediocre. The carne asada is average, as are the quesadillas.

So, to summarize, go here for the Al Pastor or the Chicken... especially if you're planning to go "super". Otherwise, this place is just like a lot of other places in the burrito corridor.
author: Angelo B.

description:
After my trip to Puerto Vallarta I have been craving chorizo tacos. I would normally go to my usual Farolito but sometimes or rather most of the time I dont have the time to stand in line.

The next best thing, Viola!!! Taqueria San Jose, their quesadilla is not as big as Farolito's and they are a bit pricey but they're good so it doesnt matter. Their fruit juices are the bomb too. The chips are actually the ones you can actually eat, they are crunchier/crispier than what they serve at Farolito's and close to what they serve at Papalote. 

I would have given it a 5 star but then again shelling $11 is a bit too much.

But you have to try it.
author: Malou C.

description: Sober or not, this is the best taqueria in the Mission by far. It's never ridiculously crowded, the quesadillas are always done to PERFECTION.
author: Phoebe B.

description: 3 stars for decent fish tacos. The salsa and pepper bar is lackluster and they dont seem to care about diner's experience. Unless they step it up soon, they're always gonna be El Farolito's spillover spot.
author: Peter K.

description:
Taqueria San Jose gives you lots of food for your money. $5 got me a burrito that I really couldn't come close to finishing, which is pretty rare for me. I don't consider myself to have a huge appetite, but I can usually finish what's in front of me.

Anyway, the food itself was OK. I really enjoyed the first few bites of my chicken burrito, but after a while I just didn't dig it. It was OVER-stuffed with meat (maybe that's your thing, but it ain't mine), and totally drippy and messy from the rather watery salsa they slopped on (even though I asked them not to).

All in all, it's definitely not TOO bad a place. I mean, I wouldn't argue with my friends if they all wanted to go there again... but the Mission is just way too rife with better options to go back to Taqueria San Jose otherwise.
author: Alex C.

description:
This place is one of those places I go for a CERTAIN item .... here ...it's the  El Pastor!    
Walk up to the counter ... do not look at the menu .... Order the El Pastor burrito.... MArtha Stewart ranked it in the top 25 best burritos in the country ... cooked to perfection.... a little spicey ... a little tangy.. a little smokey. It is a very original flavor .... almost BBQey   

Good salsa bar as well.
author: Jeremy R.

description: I rarely feel compelled to write a Yelp review because I find they're often more narcissistic than helpful, but this is an important public service announcement. You've been lied to. Sure, La Taqueria is good, in a sort of white-washed "cripsy taco" sort of way, but this place has reasonably priced Pastor tacos that are as authentic as I've ever tasted, they actually come from the real spit. Just get 4 for the price of 3, spicy style. 7 bucks. About the price of one and half cripsy taco across a street with the trendoids. The best tacos around without overpaying and their open late when you want them.
author: Trevor H.

description:
Ok, so those of you that know me, know I'm a vegetarian.  Those of you that know me REALLY well, know that I cannot resist the allure of the carne asada at this dirty little hole-in-the-wall-yet-insanely-poular taqueria.  I was first introduced to this place over three years ago by a Filipino guy I was dating.  I have since lost my love for him, but not for these super burritos.  It's a meat infused orgasm in a tortilla.  Their fruit waters are super yummy too!

The chips aren't very good though...and bring mace if you go late at night.
author: Wes M.

description:
Taquerias in the Mission evolve over time, and this is currently one of my favorites.  Just hop off the BART and grab a burrito on the way home from work.  Not the healthiest of meals, but good comfort food.

Their carnitas burritos are great and the steak is usually decent.

The grilled chicken is only mediocre - something about the sauce doesn't sit right with me.
author: Rusty S.

description:
My roommate loves this place and that alone almost made me skip writing a review for this place but...I gotta do what I gotta do.
I don't have much to say other than this I don't like having a soggy burrito...ever, not the way they are supposed to be. Even with a 2 star rating, I won't go back. most likely, I will go across the street to EL Farolito...despite the long lines.
author: James J.

description:
- They take debit cards
 - Best late night Taqueria
 - Tacos to go..... not so good!
author: Justin C.

description:
after a night of drinking what else do you do. eat donuts? no, you eat tacos. first it was 17th. then 18th. 20th. 22nd... we walked down mission like all the other junkies that my sister usually tends to at the hospital looking for her favorite taco place. back and forth we went and that's when i realized how bad i had to use the restroom. i was pretty convinced there was no way in hell i would find a restroom at 2am in the mission. 

after passing a bunch of taquerias i pre-determined a spot to do what any wasted girl would do. the bart station on the corner of 24th street and mission. the thing was i wasn't even drunk! i was pretty damn sober. as i looked at the corner getting ready to do my thing there it was. my savior. taqueria san jose. i almost cried. 

i think it was anthony bourdain who said if you want to know how clean a restaurant is, or kitchen, or something like that look at the restroom. i don't know if that's valid or not but this is probably the cleanest restroom i've come across at a taqueria or bar in SF. not what i expected at all from the mission. i don't even use the restrooms at starbucks here.

overall, it's a clean looking place even at 2am. i ordered two carne asada tacos hoping they would be as amazing as the restroom. i don't know how much the tacos cost because i didn't pay for them but i was disappointed. not the best. i will say this, the green salsa was some of the best i've had in a while. my sister ordered nachos. i don't know what kinda nachos they make but it looks like they just throw in a bunch of mission tortilla chips beans and whatever. she loved them. you might too.

i guess if you need to use the restroom or don't want to wait at the super long taco stand down the street come down here. the food is good. not amazingly good but good. there's plenty of tables and they also have a jukebox with Mexican tunes. my sister was all on that shit. i chilled and enjoyed my Mexican coke while i munched on the complimentary tortilla chips.
author: Marilu R.

description: This place is awesome! Make a trek out of the way to mission and get some baby burritos. They will fill you up!! I had carne asada and pollo adobo. Mmmmmmmm and cheap!!!! Oh and the service was very friendly
author: L. ..

description:
This is my favorite taqueria in SF. I've tried the al pastor, carnitas, and carne asada burritos and the shrimp cocktail. All were exceptional, way better than what I've had at la taqueria, la corneta, el farolito, etc nearby.

Not sure why the ratings aren't better for this place, maybe because the prices are slightly higher than the other surrounding taquerias... but I'd rather pay more for the yummier food. 

Plus it's super clean. And I love that the self serve salsa bar is refrigerated and covered.
author: Richie L.

description:
ok.  i went back.  it was a bad idea.  This place is just flat out gross - never before, and never again, will i only eat a third of the burrito and then leave because I can't take any more, despite the fact that I am STILL hungry.

Maybe if you get something other then a veggie burrito, or nachos, you actually get food that is not just lettuce and white sauce (which I want to think is watered down sour cream), then it's not one of the most disappointing experiences of your life.  I couldn't tell ya.  But I have no reason think anything other then this place is where bad burritos go when they die.
author: Tmon B.

description:
carnitas=perfection.

Salty, slightly crispy, porky in flavor, fairly greaseless...the perfect topping for a taco.  great whether you're sober or completely tanked.
author: Mike C.

description:
I remember the day I started going here pretty clearly...but I wont write about it, because it is boring.

The only thing I really eat here are the veggie tacos.  They are either awesome or not.  It depends on who's cookin' although, the same dude made my tacos two days in a row one week and they were kinda terrible the first time (no salsa, watery beans), and kinda good the second time.  

The best tacos (and the recipe seems to fluctuate wildly) I have had there include:  cheese-bonded double soft tortillas topped with pinto-beans (sometimes they like to use refried, which I think is gross), 2 types of salsa (one avacado-based, the other...well, not avacado-based), lettuce, onion and chopped tomato.

I could complain when I don't get awesome tacos, but I'd rather not bother since the whole reason for going to a taqueria in the first place is somewhat-instant, semi-greasy gratification.

{this review is actually an average of 2 and 4 stars...}
author: Maxwell M.

description:
Step 1: Get thee to thine Mission District.
Step 2:  Enter Taqueria San Jose. 
Step 3: Order tacos al Pastor with everything on them (hot sauce, too, you candy a**!)
Step 4: Eat.
Step 5: Fall in love.
Step 6: REPEAT.

There it is, people.  Best tacos outside of a taco palapa in Mexico.  Go there!
author: G R.

description: this is hands down my favorite burrito spot in frisco, super steak burrito every time, at $8 bucks its expensive but well worth it cause you get a big bag of chip with it and they just started serving sangria so you can keep the party going after hours.  never a huge line like that spot across the street and theres hella room to sit comfortably and eat.  fuck that other place this is where to go
author: Papp J.

description:
Decent burrito.
If you do not want to wait for the El Farolito late night line and do not mind paying a little bit more ($7.xx ) for a burrito then try this place.
author: Po L.

description: taqueria san jose has always been a place that i USED to go to for great authentic mexican food. it WAS definately one of my favorites. great food and decently priced, but then all of a sudden a new menu, painted walls, and  prices jumped up. WHAT THE HELL MAN, i hope you realize that there's a great chance of losing customers considering you are in competition with other awesome mexican food close by. whatever, im over it.
author: Colin H.

description:
It's been 8 months since I've been, but I remember it being so-so.  The one on International Blvd. probably has the best burrito i've had in the bay, but the meat at san jose in the mission just wasn't that great.

I do hear, though, that they have killer nachos
author: cheddar b.

description:
Obviously, this place is past its prime, and that's so sad, but I still find the pollo adobado to be the tastiest meat in the mission.  Too bad that's all they got (as far as I can tell), which makes this my second favorite taqueria after El Toro, but I'll keep going 'til they close up for good, which, judging by the amount of business they get, will be sometime soon.

The chips are a disgrace, as far as I'm concerned, but some people like them, and I'm not there for the chips.  The dining area reminds me of a morgue, except not as well-maintained.  The prices are a little insulting (DO NOT buy a veggie burrito there, it's as expensive as a meat burrito, but with less food, and not much taste; even the woman at the counter said it's a rip-off), and I've gotten gristle in my meat, but I keep going back for more (less and less often, though).  At least you'll always have a place to sit!
author: Freeman F.

description: Open late. Shorter line than Farolito. Why not. Hm...Not the best I've tried but one can be in and out in a few minutes. Major plus. Not the cleanest spot. And in all honesty, I hate the styleof the huge painting on the right wall.
author: Tania C.

description:
This is easily the worst mission burrito I've ever had. Go anywhere else and you will get better service and better food. Walk across the street to El Farolito for something delicious, or go up the block to La Corneta at 23rd for a very similar feel but dramatically better food. Rosamunde is also next door --you should consider all alternatives to this restaurant as it was absolutely terrible.

Also a homeless guy came in while we were there and was eating the leftover food nobody was cleaning up on the other tables. (He apparently also wasn't satisfied as he was picking his nose after for dessert.)

Really horrible experience. We left while the plates were still full because it wasn't worth eating. I would have rather eaten the $18 I spent on that crap.
author: Carolyn S.

description:
The fajitas and burritos were excellent.  The breakfast burrito was strange though (lots of cumin and nutmeg).  

I don't get why El Farolito across the street has a huge line but this place is empty.
author: Matthew K.

description:
the BOMB!!...regular al pastor burrito [with pineapple mixed in....sssshhhh, it's a secret!] with extra avo...intense flavors!!
the super is just toooooo much food for a sane person and the sour cream can 'soften' all the great flavors inside the burrito... 

much better joint than the "cool" hipster place cat-y corner to this one. there's great light, food is super fresh and the place is clean, and tons o places to sit. two epic murals on the wall and they have a menu with a bunch of options...delicioso.... and they don't charge for chips!!!
author: 'CJ' Edward A.

description: Not very tasty...  Plus got my order wrong.  Skip it.
author: Mason G.

description: You can grab a dependable burrito here anytime. But what are those little things that set San Jose apart from the rest? Well, first of all, there are the little quarter candy machines. Next, there is the awesome jukebox playing all your favorite Mexcian hits. Then, there is the lovely, serene mural of (what I'm assuming is) San Jose, Jalisco, Mexico. But I suppose I could be wrong about that.
author: Andrew K.

description: I have been going to Taqueria San Jose religiously for probably the past 8 years. It began one night so long ago as almost an accident. We intended to stop at El Farolito after a night of partying but the line was too long,we saw the lights on at TSJ and decided to try it out. Now I had been here years earlier as a kid but really had no recollection. Well from this night on I was hooked. I usually get the Super Carne Asada burrito, which is delicious. The other items I've tried there are the tacos and also a torta which was pretty solid also. I go to this place at all hours and honestly I've never been disappointed.
author: Nick R.

description: Sloppy seconds, the burritos are full of juicy meat and sauce derived out of the melted cheese, avacados and beans. More of a soup inside a tortilla than a traditional burrito that can be eaten with one hand. I recommend a side of chips to add texture and balance out the soupiness.
author: George M.

description: Some restaurants can be counted on to do one thing right and that's it. For me, the only thing worth eating at Taqueria San Jose are the tortas. When I'm craving a torta this is definitely my spot. If you want a tasty burrito or taco, definitely look elsewhere in the neighborhood. Like most places around here, they do a decent fresh orange & carrot juice and it's likely you'll never have to stand in line.
author: Nate R.

description:
one MUST try: Al Pastor Tacos. 

(hate to admit it, but wayyyyyy better than the local east los angeles taco trucks i grew up around)
author: Sandy H.

description: Oh how I love coming here after a proper drinkfest.  I just loooove the tacos carne asada / al pastor!
author: lulu p.

description: Their tacos are much more fresh than that "other" taqueria across the way...and the place is much cleaner.  Given how close it is to the BART station, its the perfect place for a pit stop before heading home.
author: Hector M.

description: When the bars are closed, and you're done partying--or maybe just need a snack to keep going--they're still open. At this point, who cares how good it is or what the ambiance is like? It's a taqueria. The food's decent. It's savory. It's filling. They're open late. It's serving it's purpose well, and I am a happy camper.
author: N B.

description: The al pastor tacos were pretty good, but very oily. The pico de gallo in the salsa bar looked anything but fresh. The guac was boring. But, at least the meat was tasty.
author: Tom H.

description:
A solid local place; would prefer to give them 3.5 stars, but it is local, and I love The Mission (I grew up on Dolores, Holmes!). Like a few other comments here, this place is good (bueno) to very good (muy bueno!), but with a few small changes could be excellent!!

Today, I had 2 chicken tacos ($2.20 each?) that had meat overflowing the tortilla! Great! The cerviche fish taco was also nice (with two avocado slices on top). My friend had his first meal there - he had a burrito that he LOVED! He enjoys a good burrito, and Robert said: "I love the large amount of meat, the pork is perfectly cooked. I'll come back here; and I rank this with the place we ate at in Mountain View - 6 months ago."

There are LARGE windows that look out on Mission Street, and the bathroom is clean. Its also large, not some hole in the wall joint.

OK, what could be improved to make the place excellent?

1) The cashier was unfriendly. (A Latina woman in her late 20s?) Even my friend said, "She is cold." I tried to make a small joke, and she just shut me down. No, I wasn't drunk, and no, there was no line.
2) I haven't tried everything on the menu, but there are some small things... the chips might be upgradeable; and I think I had their nachos once, and was not happy with them. (Shoot me, I'm a gringo, but I love nachos & half-nachos!!)
3) Their prices are just right for a local place, but $4.00 for a Corona seemed too high. My friend agreed. If Irish bars charge $3, and Tu Lan charges $2.25, where does the $4 come from?. Four bucks is what you charge the yuppies at La Taqueria!
4) Yes, there is something I can't put my finger on, that might make it even better... should their big tables FACE the windows? When I'm almost done, if they're not busy, could someone ask, "How is your meal? Can I get anything for you?"

Lastly, I'm not sure why all the writers fall all over La Taqueria! Is it a place for Marina yuppies? $3.50 for a taco?!?! Yes, its good, but I root for a place like Taqueria San Jose to make the small changes needed to become consistently excellent!

Do you agree? What small changes can they make to become the best??
author: M Z.

description: Mission ice cream crawl intermission. You go here for the pork tacos and the pork tacos alone. Two of us had al pastor tacos; two of us had non-pork burritos. Two of us rated this among our best taqueria experiences; the other two thought it was appalling. Fortunately, I was one of the taco-eating pair. Incredibly crisp and oily pork off the vertical spit, cilantro, onions, zingy hot sauce, $2.40 each. If you're fat-phobic, kosher or veg, this isn't your place. If you prefer burritos, well, I won't laugh at you, at least not to your face. If you're me, you can't wait to go back. Still, docked a star for making my friends queasy.
author: Brad L.

description:
i've been here tons, but haven't yelped it...

one of my favorites is the baby burrito. $3.00 for a decent mini-burrito, i think you can even get 2 for $5 of these suckers if you wink at the cashier.
author: Ameer N.

description: It's open 24-7.  It's bright and the bathroom and dining area are clean.  I get burritos elsewhere, but the tacos aren't bad.  The tables are big which is important for playing board games after we Muddy's closes Fridays at midnight.
author: Ben G.

description: Can't find a burrito joint open at 3am on a Friday?  Look no further!  I'm sure the food is great here sober, so i have been told, of course usually an a Saturday at 3 am looking for food, means that you have had a bit much to drink.....so it you're tanked...then the food will be amazing!  just don't puke it out in the car.   hahahaha......
author: A P.

description: remember to ask for your taco non-spicy.   I tried the beef taco and casadilla.  Yum and yum!  Plenty of table.  Service was quick.
author: Sydney L.

description:
fish tacos, my friends, fish tacos. grilled, yummily seasoned, no frills, simple and a tad smoky flavored = the best fish tacos in town. nope, el metate doesn't compare, other taquerias fry their fish to death and serve it up lifeless and tasteless. at taqueria san jose, 2 fish tacos, a healthy squeezing of lime and some spicy salsa, a couple of negras modelo and I AM DONE! giving 4 stars in case i find another fish taco place that's better.

UPDATE: 4/7/08
i had a fish hankering and it's been a while so off to SJT I went. But wait, $5 freakin' dollars for a bottle of modelo?! Geez! And looking at the rest of the menu, it appears that they have jacked up their prices! WHAT?! $4.40 for a super taco?! (It used to be $3.45). I'm decreaing them a star because part of the allure was the reasonable prices for delicious food. Now it is bordering on, well, let me think for a second if I want to spend that much on stuff. No way Jose.
author: ray e.

description: Let's be honest - you really only end up at Taqueria San Jose after a long night of late-night drinking. I'd like to tell you to order X, Y and Z, but the truth of the matter is, I never remember what I've ordered the next day. Their food has the magical ability to sop up free alcohol flowing through your bloodstream - the more cheese and fat the better. Strongly recommended... I think.
author: Andy T.

description: This restaurant is in a great location --- 24th and Mission but the food did not measure up to what I would expect for an authentic Mexican joint in the mission.  Plus it seemed pricy and the horchata was watery
author: ITesh J.

description: I devoured the chicken burrito I got here. Normally I don't even like burritos. And the complimentary chips were a nice bonus.
author: hello y.

description: The menu is getting a bit pricey but at 2:30 am on Friday or Saturday when the line is out the door at El Farilito, this is the spot?
author: Mingus R.

description: Definitely one of the better taquerias in the Mission.  The spicy chicken tacos were spot on and the jukebox did the trick.  Convenient location near the 24th bart station makes it easy to remember.
author: Tim G.

description: Arrived a little after dinner to find the place deserted.  Apprehensive, I tried the carne asada taco and found the meat pleasantly tender and flavorful.  The guac and salsa was generous, fresh, and refreshing.  Price about standard for mission tacos.
author: Jeremy C.

description: Wonderful food!  I had the supper burrito.  It was huge and very good. They had a large variety of salsas and guacamole, all good, though the chips were a little thick.  My husband had the carnitas, and shared with me. They were excellent as well. I especially liked the fresh squeezed orange juice.  We've eaten here twice and it has been tasty both times. They have a nice staff and clean facilities.
author: Becky C.

description: Great tasting Carne Asada Super Burrito. It's probably one of the tastiest I've had in SF. A bit on the pricey side and be prepared for a long wait if there's a crowd. If you happen to be exiting the 24th and Mission St. BART station, this place is diagonally across the street.
author: Gus L.

description: You know, you see a taqueria with a line out the door over there and then this one with nobody in it and a bell goes off. I didn't hear it.
author: Daniel P.

description: HAven't been in since like puberty, but back in the day this was one of the only spots open past 2 am.  It wasn't clean, it wasn't the best mexican food, but damn it was good at 3 am, mmm!!!
author: Aaron I.

description:
it's the mission. it's a burrito place in the mission. it has a super burrito. 


but cancun is just down the block, and it's much better. and has a better atmosphere. so i can't rag on this place since it's good, but i prob won't take it over cancun unless there is parking right on mission in front of san jose.
author: David D.

description: This place is making me fat. The unlimited chips and salsa, carnitas and carne asada plates will end me. The plates are huge, stuffed with all the usual sides of frijoles, sour cream, guac, warm tortillas and fresh greens. There is no way anybody can leave here still hungry.
author: Jordan A.

description: Skirting the dodgy deals on the Mission path from Hayes V. can really build up an appetite, so I for one was glad when my culinary adviser, Colleen l., suggested we stop in for THE best carnitas in the city. Being somewhat of an authority on all meats roasted, I was understandably skeptical at first. But, I'm happy to report the carnitas were excellent. Nicely roasted, expertly seasoned, they tasted divine. However, the chips that came with my nachos...not so good. I was glad that enough guac, cheeses, and sauces had been poured over them to help me forget what they originally tasted like...cardboard, I think. I will return, and this time, will order my carnitas in the form of a burrito.
author: Julia C.

description: best carnitas in SF hands down.... Drove by there a couple of nights ago and forgot how damn good this place was....Tell them extra crispy and they don't skimp on portions...
author: Richard G.

description: While a burrito and horchata came out rather expensive, I did enjoy them.  The grilled chicken was wonderful and the horchata authentic, with rice and cinnamon.
author: Victor R.

description:
Delish fish tacos and shrimp tacos. No rice or beans filler, which IMHO too many taquerias rely on to mask bland meat/fish/etc. Just perfectly seasoned fish & shrimp, fresh chunky salsa, wrapped in a yummy corn tortilla. Great fresh selection of salsas. Crunchy tasty chips without a spot of grease. 

Be prepared to wait, they make everything fresh to order & though it's cheap, this ain't fast food.
author: Lisa M.

description: THIS REVIEW ONLY FOCUSES ON THE TACOS.  Their al pastor, pollo, lengua, and carne asada tacos are all the best I've had outside of Mexico.  They are all liberally spiced.  Some people might consider them over-spiced, but I love it that way.  The most surprisingly good taco was the pollo, which I never order at taquerias since it's usually rather bland compared to al pastor, but here it was as spicy, tangy, and delicious as the pork or beef.  I've never noticed tendon or large chunks of fat in the meat.  The salsa bar is one of the better ones.
author: Daniel F.

description: he had tripe and cabeza tacos, i had grilled fish tacos, and chips for us both.  all of this was just short of $9, but mind you we paid for the chips since they weren't complimentary.  it's a great place for late night eats, and a good alternative to el farolito across the way (they don't serve fish, only shrimp as far as seafood goes).
author: Sheri N.
