description: The al pastor here is the best in the Misssion.  Crunchy, crispy pieces from the outer edge of the spit, juicy, buttery pieces from underneath.  When I want beef, I roll to El Farolito, but when I want swine, San Jose gets the nod.
author: David C.

description: When I go for Mexican, I usually go for beefy burritos 'cause it's my thing.  Big beefy burritos.  But every now and then, I'll get this intense craving for fish.  Just occasionally.   And that's when I'll sneak over from El Farolito's (I'm sorry, my love!)  to San Jose's.  Their fish tacos are amazingly fresh and always cooked to perfection.  Seared, almost caramelized, on the outside and flaky on the inside.  Yum.  Their salsa bar, though more expansive than Farolito's, just doesn't do it for me.  That's when I run back "home" to Farolito's begging for forgiveness.
author: Melissa S.

description: Excellent Tacos Al Pastor, served from the spit!  However, the green salsa is thicker and creamier at the Oakland branch.  Or is it a branch?  The worker said they weren't related.  5 stars for the tasty pastor goodness.
author: Derrick V.

description: Maybe I wasn't sufficiently drunk when we got here, but this place doesn't get too much of my love. To start with, the chips taste like cut-up pieces of cardboard. Now imagine the nachos - make that cardboard soggy, and top with sour cream and a little bit (emphasis on little) of cheese. Muy bien (smack your lips). The soft tacos also weren't much to write home about (I prefer taco bell, which doesn't say much). Fortunately it was cheap, so this (mis)adventure didn't break the bank.
author: Dana L.

description: I enjoy their burritos, tacos, and ceviche.  Not much to expect from a local taqueria, but you can always count on San Jose getting your order right and walking out satisfied.
author: Adrian N.

description: Terrible.  Just terrible.  The meat tasted past its prime; the horchata, gritty; and the guac, watered down.  Would I rather go McDonalds across the street? Hell yes, and I haven't been to one in years.  To sum it up, there's a reason the line's out the door at El Farolito and this place is empty.
author: Leon R.

description: This place is known for tacos al pastor, and they deliver.  My food here has always been great; the chips are good, and they have a salsa cooler that looks like a kitchen appliance but contains a number of good salsas.  The decor is a little grungy, with some hand-painted murals on the wall, a toilet that you have to get the kitchen attendants to unlock for you, and a seemingly ever-present old man drinking the same beer with the same half-eaten plate sitting at the same spot staring out the window.  Service is pretty friendly.  Definitely a good place.
author: Nils J.

description: Same menu as Taqueria No 3 in North Beach, same friendly service, but not exactly the same carnitas. Ordered the carnitas taco, and it was great, but not excellent. The pork was tender, however it didn't have that added outer layer of crispiness that I've come to expect (from too many visits to Taqueria No 3). Maybe it was just an off day. The salsa though, oh the salsa. Not sure exactly what is in the green salsa, which seems to be tomatillo, but a little thicker and spicier...
author: Nicolas H.

description: I had a Super Taco with carnitas; the meat was tender but too much was going on. I like to pick up my tacos and eat them without half of it falling back into my plastic basket. I think next time I will pass on the Super upgrade and focus on the basic taco and flavor of the meat. Watch this space.
author: Deborah S.

description: I wasn't too impressed with this place ... got a cheese enchilada, and it was aight. I'm sure there are better places on the Mission.
author: Antara B.

description: Pricey for average Mexican food, but the burritos are huge. I had a lengua burrito and it's the first time I've had tough, gristly meat. It was otherwise tasty. Nice touch that they have a covered/refrigerated salsa bar. And the jukebox is LOUD.
author: Maximillian M.

description: This place is not very good. I used to work nearby and came here maybe twice to eat. Most of what I got was bland and the chips suck. I once tried the carnitas and got TOTALLY grossed out, they were soft and dry at the same time. El Farolito is way better albeit greasier!
author: Gina R.

description: Went here after seeing the crazy line at El Farolitos and was reminded of why i stopped coming 3 years ago. 9$ burrito should get you a pretty d*mn good burrito in the mission; not the case here. Super burrito was cold, sour cream was watered down, just disappointing. If I remember correctly, their nachos are decent.
author: Kellen C.

description: I love this place. I usually order the super vegetarian taco here and it never disappoints. It is basically a mexican platter, under the guise of a taco. If you get it to go it is practically busting out of the styrofoam take-out container as it is heavily-laden with veggies and rice. There is hardly ever a line and there is a self-serve salsa bar, something missing from many of the other places in the vacinity.
author: Mark H.

description:
It's good for late-nite stuff, but it is not on par with the other taquerias. 

I cannot put my finger on it but there is just something not right with the burrito. It was good enough for its purpose, but I would not go to this place again unless I had to.
author: Rahul T.

description: I've tried a lot of places in the mission, but my heart always goes back to this place. The "special" plate with two tacos, beans, and avocados looks so pretty and tastes marvelous. The burritos are fantastic, and I love the pic of the guy who is making your food on the wall when you walk in. Mario Batali listed this place as one of the top tacos in the country.
author: Mama C.

description:
get the fish tacos!!! for dinner one night, we decided to order three little things: a ceviche tostada, a shrimp taco, and an al pastor taco. the al pastor here is weird and tastes way too much like it was smothered in american-style bbq sauce. it wasn't bad but just not really what you expect. the ceviche tostada was tasty but a little too limey. the shrimp taco was decent but doesn't have all that much flavor. 

still a little hungry, we ordered one last thing to round out the meal: a fish taco. this last taco blew us away - the fillet of fish on the taco was so flavorful! we went back again late one night after parties and ordered two fish tacos and again, delicious!

update 7/2007: i was feeling adventurous and tried out a tripas taco here. it was really nicely crunchy and low on tripey-funky-aftertaste. muy delicioso!
author: Angi C.

description: Try the fish tacos. I see the other reviews are concentrating on the al pastor and carnitas. But try the fish tacos. They are really good. They don't deep fry the fish, wish is key. They sautee small chunks of (guessing) talapia, cover it with minced red onion and chopped cilantro and squeeze some lime on it. That's it. Fantastic. As far as I know, this is only taqueria that makes fish tacos this way. With a beer and football games on TV, lunch here on a weekend is a joy.
author: Kourosh K.

description: I've only been here once and I loved the carne asada burrito. Big, fat, full of meat (w/ avocado), and not soggy --- yum! Enough said!
author: Betty L.

description:
Drinks here are outrageously priced.
$4.00 for a domestic? cmon this is just a regular sh*t hole taqueria

Chips are NOT homemade.

I had three tacos.
- Carne Asada = nothing special, boring and bland 
- Grilled Chicken = terrible
- Carnitas = the best of the three but nothing special considering how good most of th other taquerias in the area are
author: Henry C.

description: These tacos are bomb. Absolute bomb. And at a complete neighborhood service, one of the only digestable eateries open very late at night, they are perfect, really for any time of the day, or when the vampires are trolling around. Lestat, come back with my taco!!!!
author: Lucian J.

description: damn good tacos, especially because everything in the mission closes so damn early. i came here on a friday night at about 9:30 looking for a taco or pupusa because i wasn't satisfied with my meal at Home in the castro. i settled on taqueria san jose as not much was left open other than el farolito, which was still pretty packed so taqueria san jose it was. 2.21 plus tax (kind of expensive) for a pollo taco, which was hot and greasy. the salsa and spices were plenty hot and spicy, and the taco was made fresh to order, so it was piping hot too. it was a legit taco. i've read about their burritos and other plates, and they don't sound too enticing, but their tacos are legit. if you want some cheaper tacos or good burritos though, you can hit la taqueria, el farolito, or anything down 24th street. all of those taquerias are legit, especially vallarta, and they're much cheaper, but for a hot, lat-night taco, taqueria san jose isn't a bad choice.
author: Danny C.

description: I've learned my lesson: When you find The One, never ever stray. I went here instead of my trusty Farolito just to try something different. I should have noticed the red flags. There was nobody inside and I got my order way too quickly. The veggie burrito was lukewarm, soggy, and loosely wrapped, so everything started to fall out when I unwrapped it. It was supposed to come with avocado, but I could barely taste any. For $7 (which is more than a super burrito at Farolito!) I was really disappointed. Never again.
author: Tammy C.

description: i would have given this place 6 stars. friendly service and good food. but they just raised their prices which bums me out as they were already on the pricey side.
author: Wayne T.

description: not the best place carne asada wasnt that great super chicken quesadilla was decent , very fast service though !
author: NAEL K.

description: our food tasty benefit ran out of food... we didnt really get any... so we had to eat something! we randomly picked mexican, then went to the mission and randomly walked into this place. it's just an order at the counter, and they bring you some food type place. b didnt like his fajita. s loved his pork tacos. j liked his pork enchiladas and my chicken ones were ok. i think s wants to come back for tacos.... but i would not come back here on purpose. it was just eh. not bad not good. except for the strawberry water... that was the best i've had so far. cheap tho... mine came out to less than $15.  you get  a lot of food (3 enchiladas with toppings, nachos rice beans...). and empty on a wednesday evening.
author: Merredith L.

description: my first taco experience in san francisco and one i keep coming back to. the choizo taco is incredible. spicy, saucy, flavorful. i like the pollo and carnitas and other ones as well, but it's the chorizo one that makes my mouth water.
author: dannebrog ..

description: A bit expensive for what you get.  I like taquerias who fry their own chips too.
author: Antony E.

description: The absolute best pollo asado tacos in the city- and as a pollo asado taco freak, I have tried a good number of them. The pollo is heavily marinated and cooked to perfection, with the right amount of spice, cilantro, onions and sauce. Prices are good and it's open late. You don't get flavor like this at El Farolito- it amazes me people go there instead of here for their late night taco fix.
author: Jonathan M.

description: i'm surprised that nobody commented on their taco chorizo.  in addition to the chorizo, i ordered their version of the al pastor and found it be fairly mediocre to california standards (however, it was really great for NY standards).  but the star of this restaurant was their taco chorizo.  minute cuts of DELICIOUS chopped fatty pork, seasoned with chili and paprika in a soft fresh tortilla.  the flavors truly burst'd in my mouth, and the sides (tomato, onions, lime slices) only complimented it, however, they weren't necessary.  it was easily the highlight of my first mission-style latino experience, next to my first REAL burrito de cabeza just a few doors down at La Taqueria.  my plane had landed only an hour prior to my first visit at this establishment.  it was around 3pm in the afternoon on a peaceful friday.  business was slow and i was the only customer there.  it's moments like these that made me pause, and think to myself: "life is fucking beautiful in california."
author: Hugo B.
